     2url: "https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview"
     3title: "Claude Code overview - Anthropic"
     4---
     5
     6[Anthropic home page![light logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/light.svg)![dark logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/dark.svg)](https://docs.anthropic.com/)

    17
    18Getting started
    19
    20Claude Code overview
    21
    22[Welcome](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/home) [Developer Platform](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/intro) [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview) [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/mcp) [API Reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages) [Resources](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/resources/overview) [Release Notes](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/release-notes/overview)
    23
    24## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview\#get-started-in-30-seconds)  Get started in 30 seconds
    25
    26Prerequisites: [Node.js 18 or newer](https://nodejs.org/en/download/)
    27
    28Copy
    29
    30```bash
    31# Install Claude Code
    32npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code
    33
    34# Navigate to your project
    35cd your-awesome-project
    36
    37# Start coding with Claude
    38claude
    39
    40```
    41
    42Thats it! Youre ready to start coding with Claude. [Continue with Quickstart (5 mins) ](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/quickstart)
    43
    44(Got specific setup needs or hit issues? See [advanced setup](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup) or [troubleshooting](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/troubleshooting).)
    45
    46## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview\#what-claude-code-does-for-you)  What Claude Code does for you
    47
    48- **Build features from descriptions**: Tell Claude what you want to build in plain English. It will make a plan, write the code, and ensure it works.
    49- **Debug and fix issues**: Describe a bug or paste an error message. Claude Code will analyze your codebase, identify the problem, and implement a fix.
    50- **Navigate any codebase**: Ask anything about your teams codebase, and get a thoughtful answer back. Claude Code maintains awareness of your entire project structure, can find up-to-date information from the web, and with [MCP](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/mcp) can pull from external datasources like Google Drive, Figma, and Slack.
    51- **Automate tedious tasks**: Fix fiddly lint issues, resolve merge conflicts, and write release notes. Do all this in a single command from your developer machines, or automatically in CI.
    52
    53## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview\#why-developers-love-claude-code)  Why developers love Claude Code
    54
    55- **Works in your terminal**: Not another chat window. Not another IDE. Claude Code meets you where you already work, with the tools you already love.
    56- **Takes action**: Claude Code can directly edit files, run commands, and create commits. Need more? [MCP](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/mcp) lets Claude read your design docs in Google Drive, update your tickets in Jira, or use _your_ custom developer tooling.
    57- **Unix philosophy**: Claude Code is composable and scriptable. `tail -f app.log | claude -p "Slack me if you see any anomalies appear in this log stream"` _works_. Your CI can run `claude -p "If there are new text strings, translate them into French and raise a PR for @lang-fr-team to review"`.
    58- **Enterprise-ready**: Use Anthropics API, or host on AWS or GCP. Enterprise-grade [security](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/security), [privacy](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/data-usage), and [compliance](https://trust.anthropic.com/) is built-in.
    59
    60## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview\#next-steps)  Next steps
    61

[Anthropic home page![light logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/light.svg)![dark logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/dark.svg)](https://docs.anthropic.com/)

English

Search...

Ctrl K

Search...

Navigation

Getting started

Claude Code overview

[Welcome](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/home) [Developer Platform](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/intro) [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview) [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/mcp) [API Reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages) [Resources](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/resources/overview) [Release Notes](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/release-notes/overview)

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview\#get-started-in-30-seconds)  Get started in 30 seconds

Prerequisites: [Node.js 18 or newer](https://nodejs.org/en/download/)

Copy

```bash
# Install Claude Code
npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code

# Navigate to your project
cd your-awesome-project

# Start coding with Claude
claude

```

Thats it! Youre ready to start coding with Claude. [Continue with Quickstart (5 mins) ](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/quickstart)

(Got specific setup needs or hit issues? See [advanced setup](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup) or [troubleshooting](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/troubleshooting).)

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview\#what-claude-code-does-for-you)  What Claude Code does for you

- **Build features from descriptions**: Tell Claude what you want to build in plain English. It will make a plan, write the code, and ensure it works.
- **Debug and fix issues**: Describe a bug or paste an error message. Claude Code will analyze your codebase, identify the problem, and implement a fix.
- **Navigate any codebase**: Ask anything about your teams codebase, and get a thoughtful answer back. Claude Code maintains awareness of your entire project structure, can find up-to-date information from the web, and with [MCP](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/mcp) can pull from external datasources like Google Drive, Figma, and Slack.
- **Automate tedious tasks**: Fix fiddly lint issues, resolve merge conflicts, and write release notes. Do all this in a single command from your developer machines, or automatically in CI.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview\#why-developers-love-claude-code)  Why developers love Claude Code

- **Works in your terminal**: Not another chat window. Not another IDE. Claude Code meets you where you already work, with the tools you already love.
- **Takes action**: Claude Code can directly edit files, run commands, and create commits. Need more? [MCP](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/mcp) lets Claude read your design docs in Google Drive, update your tickets in Jira, or use _your_ custom developer tooling.
- **Unix philosophy**: Claude Code is composable and scriptable. `tail -f app.log | claude -p "Slack me if you see any anomalies appear in this log stream"` _works_. Your CI can run `claude -p "If there are new text strings, translate them into French and raise a PR for @lang-fr-team to review"`.
- **Enterprise-ready**: Use Anthropics API, or host on AWS or GCP. Enterprise-grade [security](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/security), [privacy](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/data-usage), and [compliance](https://trust.anthropic.com/) is built-in.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview\#next-steps)  Next steps

[**Quickstart** \\
\\
See Claude Code in action with practical examples](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/quickstart) [**Common workflows** \\
\\
Step-by-step guides for common workflows](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows) [**Troubleshooting** \\
\\
Solutions for common issues with Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/troubleshooting) [**IDE setup** \\
\\
Add Claude Code to your IDE](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/ide-integrations)

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview\#additional-resources)  Additional resources

[**Host on AWS or GCP** \\
\\
Configure Claude Code with Amazon Bedrock or Google Vertex AI](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/third-party-integrations) [**Settings** \\
\\
Customize Claude Code for your workflow](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings) [**Commands** \\
\\
Learn about CLI commands and controls](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/cli-reference) [**Reference implementation** \\
\\
Clone our development container reference implementation](https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code/tree/main/.devcontainer) [**Security** \\
\\
Discover Claude Codes safeguards and best practices for safe usage](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/security) [**Privacy and data usage** \\
\\
Understand how Claude Code handles your data](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/data-usage)

1---
     2url: "https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents"
     3title: "Subagents - Anthropic"
     4---
     5
     6[Anthropic home page![light logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/light.svg)![dark logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/dark.svg)](https://docs.anthropic.com/)
     7
     8English
     9
    10Search...
    11
    12Ctrl K
    13
    14Search...
    15
    16Navigation
    17
    18Build with Claude Code
    19
    20Subagents
    21
    22[Welcome](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/home) [Developer Platform](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/intro) [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview) [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/mcp) [API Reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages) [Resources](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/resources/overview) [Release Notes](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/release-notes/overview)
    23
    24Custom subagents in Claude Code are specialized AI assistants that can be invoked to handle specific types of tasks. They enable more efficient problem-solving by providing task-specific configurations with customized system prompts, tools and a separate context window.
    25
    26## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#what-are-subagents%3F)  What are subagents?
    27
    28Subagents are pre-configured AI personalities that Claude Code can delegate tasks to. Each subagent:
    29
    30- Has a specific purpose and expertise area
    31- Uses its own context window separate from the main conversation
    32- Can be configured with specific tools its allowed to use
    33- Includes a custom system prompt that guides its behavior
    34
    35When Claude Code encounters a task that matches a subagents expertise, it can delegate that task to the specialized subagent, which works independently and returns results.
    36
    37## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#key-benefits)  Key benefits
    38
    39## Context preservation
    40
    41Each subagent operates in its own context, preventing pollution of the main conversation and keeping it focused on high-level objectives.
    42
    43## Specialized expertise
    44
    45Subagents can be fine-tuned with detailed instructions for specific domains, leading to higher success rates on designated tasks.
    46
    47## Reusability
    48
    49Once created, subagents can be used across different projects and shared with your team for consistent workflows.
    50
    51## Flexible permissions
    52
    53Each subagent can have different tool access levels, allowing you to limit powerful tools to specific subagent types.
    54
    55## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#quick-start)  Quick start
    56
    57To create your first subagent:
    58
    591
    60
    61Open the subagents interface
    62
    63Run the following command:
    64
    65Copy
    66
    67```
    68/agents
    69
    70```
    71
    722
    73
    74Select 'Create New Agent'
    75
    76Choose whether to create a project-level or user-level subagent
    77
    783
    79
    80Define the subagent
    81
    82- **Recommended**: Generate with Claude first, then customize to make it yours
    83- Describe your subagent in detail and when it should be used
    84- Select the tools you want to grant access to (or leave blank to inherit all tools)
    85- The interface shows all available tools, making selection easy
    86- If youre generating with Claude, you can also edit the system prompt in your own editor by pressing `e`
    87
    884
    89
    90Save and use
    91
    92Your subagent is now available! Claude will use it automatically when appropriate, or you can invoke it explicitly:
    93
    94Copy
    95
    96```
    97> Use the code-reviewer subagent to check my recent changes
    98
    99```
   100
   101## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#subagent-configuration)  Subagent configuration
   102
   103### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#file-locations)  File locations
   104
   105Subagents are stored as Markdown files with YAML frontmatter in two possible locations:
   106
   107| Type | Location | Scope | Priority |
   108| --- | --- | --- | --- |
   109| **Project subagents** | `.claude/agents/` | Available in current project | Highest |
   110| **User subagents** | `~/.claude/agents/` | Available across all projects | Lower |
   111
   112When subagent names conflict, project-level subagents take precedence over user-level subagents.
   113
   114### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#file-format)  File format
   115
   116Each subagent is defined in a Markdown file with this structure:
   117
   118Copy
   119
   120```markdown
   121---
   122name: your-sub-agent-name
   123description: Description of when this subagent should be invoked
   124tools: tool1, tool2, tool3  # Optional - inherits all tools if omitted
   125---
   126
   127Your subagent's system prompt goes here. This can be multiple paragraphs
   128and should clearly define the subagent's role, capabilities, and approach
   129to solving problems.
   130
   131Include specific instructions, best practices, and any constraints
   132the subagent should follow.
   133
   134```
   135
   136#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#configuration-fields)  Configuration fields
   137
   138| Field | Required | Description |
   139| --- | --- | --- |
   140| `name` | Yes | Unique identifier using lowercase letters and hyphens |
   141| `description` | Yes | Natural language description of the subagents purpose |
   142| `tools` | No | Comma-separated list of specific tools. If omitted, inherits all tools from the main thread |
   143
   144### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#available-tools)  Available tools
   145
   146Subagents can be granted access to any of Claude Codes internal tools. See the [tools documentation](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings#tools-available-to-claude) for a complete list of available tools.
   147
   148**Recommended:** Use the `/agents` command to modify tool access - it provides an interactive interface that lists all available tools, including any connected MCP server tools, making it easier to select the ones you need.
   149
   150You have two options for configuring tools:
   151
   152- **Omit the `tools` field** to inherit all tools from the main thread (default), including MCP tools
   153- **Specify individual tools** as a comma-separated list for more granular control (can be edited manually or via `/agents`)
   154
   155**MCP Tools**: Subagents can access MCP tools from configured MCP servers. When the `tools` field is omitted, subagents inherit all MCP tools available to the main thread.
   156
   157## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#managing-subagents)  Managing subagents
   158
   159### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#using-the-%2Fagents-command-recommended)  Using the /agents command (Recommended)
   160
   161The `/agents` command provides a comprehensive interface for subagent management:
   162
   163Copy
   164
   165```
   166/agents
   167
   168```
   169
   170This opens an interactive menu where you can:
   171
   172- View all available subagents (built-in, user, and project)
   173- Create new subagents with guided setup
   174- Edit existing custom subagents, including their tool access
   175- Delete custom subagents
   176- See which subagents are active when duplicates exist
   177- **Easily manage tool permissions** with a complete list of available tools
   178
   179### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#direct-file-management)  Direct file management
   180
   181You can also manage subagents by working directly with their files:
   182
   183Copy
   184
   185```bash
   186# Create a project subagent
   187mkdir -p .claude/agents
   188echo '---
   189name: test-runner
   190description: Use proactively to run tests and fix failures
   191---
   192
   193You are a test automation expert. When you see code changes, proactively run the appropriate tests. If tests fail, analyze the failures and fix them while preserving the original test intent.' > .claude/agents/test-runner.md
   194
   195# Create a user subagent
   196mkdir -p ~/.claude/agents
   197# ... create subagent file
   198
   199```
   200
   201## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#using-subagents-effectively)  Using subagents effectively
   202
   203### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#automatic-delegation)  Automatic delegation
   204
   205Claude Code proactively delegates tasks based on:
   206
   207- The task description in your request
   208- The `description` field in subagent configurations
   209- Current context and available tools
   210
   211To encourage more proactive subagent use, include phrases like use PROACTIVELY or MUST BE USED in your `description` field.
   212
   213### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#explicit-invocation)  Explicit invocation
   214
   215Request a specific subagent by mentioning it in your command:
   216
   217Copy
   218
   219```
   220> Use the test-runner subagent to fix failing tests
   221> Have the code-reviewer subagent look at my recent changes
   222> Ask the debugger subagent to investigate this error
   223
   224```
   225
   226## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#example-subagents)  Example subagents
   227
   228### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#code-reviewer)  Code reviewer
   229
   230Copy
   231
   232```markdown
   233---
   234name: code-reviewer
   235description: Expert code review specialist. Proactively reviews code for quality, security, and maintainability. Use immediately after writing or modifying code.
   236tools: Read, Grep, Glob, Bash
   237---
   238
   239You are a senior code reviewer ensuring high standards of code quality and security.
   240
   241When invoked:
   2421. Run git diff to see recent changes
   2432. Focus on modified files
   2443. Begin review immediately
   245
   246Review checklist:
   247- Code is simple and readable
   248- Functions and variables are well-named
   249- No duplicated code
   250- Proper error handling
   251- No exposed secrets or API keys
   252- Input validation implemented
   253- Good test coverage
   254- Performance considerations addressed
   255
   256Provide feedback organized by priority:
   257- Critical issues (must fix)
   258- Warnings (should fix)
   259- Suggestions (consider improving)
   260
   261Include specific examples of how to fix issues.
   262
   263```
   264
   265### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#debugger)  Debugger
   266
   267Copy
   268
   269```markdown
   270---
   271name: debugger
   272description: Debugging specialist for errors, test failures, and unexpected behavior. Use proactively when encountering any issues.
   273tools: Read, Edit, Bash, Grep, Glob
   274---
   275
   276You are an expert debugger specializing in root cause analysis.
   277
   278When invoked:
   2791. Capture error message and stack trace
   2802. Identify reproduction steps
   2813. Isolate the failure location
   2824. Implement minimal fix
   2835. Verify solution works
   284
   285Debugging process:
   286- Analyze error messages and logs
   287- Check recent code changes
   288- Form and test hypotheses
   289- Add strategic debug logging
   290- Inspect variable states
   291
   292For each issue, provide:
   293- Root cause explanation
   294- Evidence supporting the diagnosis
   295- Specific code fix
   296- Testing approach
   297- Prevention recommendations
   298
   299Focus on fixing the underlying issue, not just symptoms.
   300
   301```
   302
   303### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#data-scientist)  Data scientist
   304
   305Copy
   306
   307```markdown
   308---
   309name: data-scientist
   310description: Data analysis expert for SQL queries, BigQuery operations, and data insights. Use proactively for data analysis tasks and queries.
   311tools: Bash, Read, Write
   312---
   313
   314You are a data scientist specializing in SQL and BigQuery analysis.
   315
   316When invoked:
   3171. Understand the data analysis requirement
   3182. Write efficient SQL queries
   3193. Use BigQuery command line tools (bq) when appropriate
   3204. Analyze and summarize results
   3215. Present findings clearly
   322
   323Key practices:
   324- Write optimized SQL queries with proper filters
   325- Use appropriate aggregations and joins
   326- Include comments explaining complex logic
   327- Format results for readability
   328- Provide data-driven recommendations
   329
   330For each analysis:
   331- Explain the query approach
   332- Document any assumptions
   333- Highlight key findings
   334- Suggest next steps based on data
   335
   336Always ensure queries are efficient and cost-effective.
   337
   338```
   339
   340## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#best-practices)  Best practices
   341
   342- **Start with Claude-generated agents**: We highly recommend generating your initial subagent with Claude and then iterating on it to make it personally yours. This approach gives you the best results - a solid foundation that you can customize to your specific needs.
   343
   344- **Design focused subagents**: Create subagents with single, clear responsibilities rather than trying to make one subagent do everything. This improves performance and makes subagents more predictable.
   345
   346- **Write detailed prompts**: Include specific instructions, examples, and constraints in your system prompts. The more guidance you provide, the better the subagent will perform.
   347
   348- **Limit tool access**: Only grant tools that are necessary for the subagents purpose. This improves security and helps the subagent focus on relevant actions.
   349
   350- **Version control**: Check project subagents into version control so your team can benefit from and improve them collaboratively.
   351
   352
   353## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#advanced-usage)  Advanced usage
   354
   355### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#chaining-subagents)  Chaining subagents
   356
   357For complex workflows, you can chain multiple subagents:
   358
   359Copy
   360
   361```
   362> First use the code-analyzer subagent to find performance issues, then use the optimizer subagent to fix them
   363
   364```
   365
   366### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#dynamic-subagent-selection)  Dynamic subagent selection
   367
   368Claude Code intelligently selects subagents based on context. Make your `description` fields specific and action-oriented for best results.
   369
   370## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#performance-considerations)  Performance considerations
   371
   372- **Context efficiency**: Agents help preserve main context, enabling longer overall sessions
   373- **Latency**: Subagents start off with a clean slate each time they are invoked and may add latency as they gather context that they require to do their job effectively.
   374
   375## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#related-documentation)  Related documentation
   376
   377- [Slash commands](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/slash-commands) \- Learn about other built-in commands
   378- [Settings](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings) \- Configure Claude Code behavior
   379- [Hooks](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks) \- Automate workflows with event handlers
   380
   381Was this page helpful?
   382
   383YesNo
   384
   385[Claude Code SDK](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sdk) [Claude Code hooks](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks-guide)
   386
   387On this page
   388
   389- [What are subagents?](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents#what-are-subagents%3F)
   390- [Key benefits](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents#key-benefits)
   391- [Quick start](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents#quick-start)
   392- [Subagent configuration](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents#subagent-configuration)
   393- [File locations](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents#file-locations)
   394- [File format](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents#file-format)

   398- [Using the /agents command (Recommended)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents#using-the-%2Fagents-command-recommended)
   399- [Direct file management](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents#direct-file-management)
   400- [Using subagents effectively](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents#using-subagents-effectively)

English

Build with Claude Code

Subagents

[Welcome](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/home) [Developer Platform](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/intro) [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview) [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/mcp) [API Reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages) [Resources](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/resources/overview) [Release Notes](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/release-notes/overview)

Custom subagents in Claude Code are specialized AI assistants that can be invoked to handle specific types of tasks. They enable more efficient problem-solving by providing task-specific configurations with customized system prompts, tools and a separate context window.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#what-are-subagents%3F)  What are subagents?

Subagents are pre-configured AI personalities that Claude Code can delegate tasks to. Each subagent:

- Has a specific purpose and expertise area
- Uses its own context window separate from the main conversation
- Can be configured with specific tools its allowed to use
- Includes a custom system prompt that guides its behavior

When Claude Code encounters a task that matches a subagents expertise, it can delegate that task to the specialized subagent, which works independently and returns results.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#key-benefits)  Key benefits

## Context preservation

Each subagent operates in its own context, preventing pollution of the main conversation and keeping it focused on high-level objectives.

## Specialized expertise

Subagents can be fine-tuned with detailed instructions for specific domains, leading to higher success rates on designated tasks.

## Reusability

Once created, subagents can be used across different projects and shared with your team for consistent workflows.

## Flexible permissions

Each subagent can have different tool access levels, allowing you to limit powerful tools to specific subagent types.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#quick-start)  Quick start

To create your first subagent:

1

Open the subagents interface

Run the following command:

Copy

```
/agents

```

2

Select 'Create New Agent'

Choose whether to create a project-level or user-level subagent

3

Define the subagent

- **Recommended**: Generate with Claude first, then customize to make it yours
- Describe your subagent in detail and when it should be used
- Select the tools you want to grant access to (or leave blank to inherit all tools)
- The interface shows all available tools, making selection easy
- If youre generating with Claude, you can also edit the system prompt in your own editor by pressing `e`

4

Save and use

Your subagent is now available! Claude will use it automatically when appropriate, or you can invoke it explicitly:

Copy

```
> Use the code-reviewer subagent to check my recent changes

```

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#subagent-configuration)  Subagent configuration

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#file-locations)  File locations

Subagents are stored as Markdown files with YAML frontmatter in two possible locations:

| Type | Location | Scope | Priority |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Project subagents** | `.claude/agents/` | Available in current project | Highest |
| **User subagents** | `~/.claude/agents/` | Available across all projects | Lower |

When subagent names conflict, project-level subagents take precedence over user-level subagents.

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#file-format)  File format

Each subagent is defined in a Markdown file with this structure:

Copy

```markdown
---
name: your-sub-agent-name
description: Description of when this subagent should be invoked
tools: tool1, tool2, tool3  # Optional - inherits all tools if omitted
---

Your subagent's system prompt goes here. This can be multiple paragraphs
and should clearly define the subagent's role, capabilities, and approach
to solving problems.

Include specific instructions, best practices, and any constraints
the subagent should follow.

```

#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#configuration-fields)  Configuration fields

| Field | Required | Description |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `name` | Yes | Unique identifier using lowercase letters and hyphens |
| `description` | Yes | Natural language description of the subagents purpose |
| `tools` | No | Comma-separated list of specific tools. If omitted, inherits all tools from the main thread |

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#available-tools)  Available tools

Subagents can be granted access to any of Claude Codes internal tools. See the [tools documentation](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings#tools-available-to-claude) for a complete list of available tools.

**Recommended:** Use the `/agents` command to modify tool access - it provides an interactive interface that lists all available tools, including any connected MCP server tools, making it easier to select the ones you need.

You have two options for configuring tools:

- **Omit the `tools` field** to inherit all tools from the main thread (default), including MCP tools
- **Specify individual tools** as a comma-separated list for more granular control (can be edited manually or via `/agents`)

**MCP Tools**: Subagents can access MCP tools from configured MCP servers. When the `tools` field is omitted, subagents inherit all MCP tools available to the main thread.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#managing-subagents)  Managing subagents

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#using-the-%2Fagents-command-recommended)  Using the /agents command (Recommended)

The `/agents` command provides a comprehensive interface for subagent management:

Copy

```
/agents

```

This opens an interactive menu where you can:

- View all available subagents (built-in, user, and project)
- Create new subagents with guided setup
- Edit existing custom subagents, including their tool access
- Delete custom subagents
- See which subagents are active when duplicates exist
- **Easily manage tool permissions** with a complete list of available tools

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#direct-file-management)  Direct file management

You can also manage subagents by working directly with their files:

Copy

```bash
# Create a project subagent
mkdir -p .claude/agents
echo '---
name: test-runner
description: Use proactively to run tests and fix failures
---

You are a test automation expert. When you see code changes, proactively run the appropriate tests. If tests fail, analyze the failures and fix them while preserving the original test intent.' > .claude/agents/test-runner.md

# Create a user subagent
mkdir -p ~/.claude/agents
# ... create subagent file

```

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#using-subagents-effectively)  Using subagents effectively

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#automatic-delegation)  Automatic delegation

Claude Code proactively delegates tasks based on:

- The task description in your request
- The `description` field in subagent configurations
- Current context and available tools

To encourage more proactive subagent use, include phrases like use PROACTIVELY or MUST BE USED in your `description` field.

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#explicit-invocation)  Explicit invocation

Request a specific subagent by mentioning it in your command:

Copy

```
> Use the test-runner subagent to fix failing tests
> Have the code-reviewer subagent look at my recent changes
> Ask the debugger subagent to investigate this error

```

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#example-subagents)  Example subagents

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#code-reviewer)  Code reviewer

Copy

```markdown
---
name: code-reviewer
description: Expert code review specialist. Proactively reviews code for quality, security, and maintainability. Use immediately after writing or modifying code.
tools: Read, Grep, Glob, Bash
---

You are a senior code reviewer ensuring high standards of code quality and security.

When invoked:
1. Run git diff to see recent changes
2. Focus on modified files
3. Begin review immediately

Review checklist:
- Code is simple and readable
- Functions and variables are well-named
- No duplicated code
- Proper error handling
- No exposed secrets or API keys
- Input validation implemented
- Good test coverage
- Performance considerations addressed

Provide feedback organized by priority:
- Critical issues (must fix)
- Warnings (should fix)
- Suggestions (consider improving)

Include specific examples of how to fix issues.

```

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#debugger)  Debugger

Copy

```markdown
---
name: debugger
description: Debugging specialist for errors, test failures, and unexpected behavior. Use proactively when encountering any issues.
tools: Read, Edit, Bash, Grep, Glob
---

You are an expert debugger specializing in root cause analysis.

When invoked:
1. Capture error message and stack trace
2. Identify reproduction steps
3. Isolate the failure location
4. Implement minimal fix
5. Verify solution works

Debugging process:
- Analyze error messages and logs
- Check recent code changes
- Form and test hypotheses
- Add strategic debug logging
- Inspect variable states

For each issue, provide:
- Root cause explanation
- Evidence supporting the diagnosis
- Specific code fix
- Testing approach
- Prevention recommendations

Focus on fixing the underlying issue, not just symptoms.

```

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#data-scientist)  Data scientist

Copy

```markdown
---
name: data-scientist
description: Data analysis expert for SQL queries, BigQuery operations, and data insights. Use proactively for data analysis tasks and queries.
tools: Bash, Read, Write
---

You are a data scientist specializing in SQL and BigQuery analysis.

When invoked:
1. Understand the data analysis requirement
2. Write efficient SQL queries
3. Use BigQuery command line tools (bq) when appropriate
4. Analyze and summarize results
5. Present findings clearly

Key practices:
- Write optimized SQL queries with proper filters
- Use appropriate aggregations and joins
- Include comments explaining complex logic
- Format results for readability
- Provide data-driven recommendations

For each analysis:
- Explain the query approach
- Document any assumptions
- Highlight key findings
- Suggest next steps based on data

Always ensure queries are efficient and cost-effective.

```

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#best-practices)  Best practices

- **Start with Claude-generated agents**: We highly recommend generating your initial subagent with Claude and then iterating on it to make it personally yours. This approach gives you the best results - a solid foundation that you can customize to your specific needs.

- **Design focused subagents**: Create subagents with single, clear responsibilities rather than trying to make one subagent do everything. This improves performance and makes subagents more predictable.

- **Write detailed prompts**: Include specific instructions, examples, and constraints in your system prompts. The more guidance you provide, the better the subagent will perform.

- **Limit tool access**: Only grant tools that are necessary for the subagents purpose. This improves security and helps the subagent focus on relevant actions.

- **Version control**: Check project subagents into version control so your team can benefit from and improve them collaboratively.


## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#advanced-usage)  Advanced usage

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#chaining-subagents)  Chaining subagents

For complex workflows, you can chain multiple subagents:

Copy

```
> First use the code-analyzer subagent to find performance issues, then use the optimizer subagent to fix them

```

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#dynamic-subagent-selection)  Dynamic subagent selection

Claude Code intelligently selects subagents based on context. Make your `description` fields specific and action-oriented for best results.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#performance-considerations)  Performance considerations

- **Context efficiency**: Agents help preserve main context, enabling longer overall sessions
- **Latency**: Subagents start off with a clean slate each time they are invoked and may add latency as they gather context that they require to do their job effectively.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#related-documentation)  Related documentation

- [Slash commands](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/slash-commands) \- Learn about other built-in commands
- [Settings](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings) \- Configure Claude Code behavior
- [Hooks](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks) \- Automate workflows with event handlers

Was this page helpful?

YesNo

[Claude Code SDK](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sdk) [Claude Code hooks](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks-guide)

On this page

- [What are subagents?](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents#what-are-subagents%3F)

    23
    24Claude Code can remember your preferences across sessions, like style guidelines and common commands in your workflow.
    25
    26## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#determine-memory-type)  Determine memory type
    27
    28Claude Code offers three memory locations, each serving a different purpose:
    29
    30| Memory Type | Location | Purpose | Use Case Examples |
    31| --- | --- | --- | --- |
    32| **Project memory** | `./CLAUDE.md` | Team-shared instructions for the project | Project architecture, coding standards, common workflows |
    33| **User memory** | `~/.claude/CLAUDE.md` | Personal preferences for all projects | Code styling preferences, personal tooling shortcuts |
    34| **Project memory (local)** | `./CLAUDE.local.md` | Personal project-specific preferences | _(Deprecated, see below)_ Your sandbox URLs, preferred test data |
    35
    36All memory files are automatically loaded into Claude Codes context when launched.
    37
    38## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#claude-md-imports)  CLAUDE.md imports
    39
    40CLAUDE.md files can import additional files using `@path/to/import` syntax. The following example imports 3 files:
    41
    42Copy
    43
    44```
    45See @README for project overview and @package.json for available npm commands for this project.
    46
    47# Additional Instructions
    48- git workflow @docs/git-instructions.md
    49
    50```
    51
    52Both relative and absolute paths are allowed. In particular, importing files in users home dir is a convenient way for your team members to provide individual instructions that are not checked into the repository. Previously CLAUDE.local.md served a similar purpose, but is now deprecated in favor of imports since they work better across multiple git worktrees.
    53
    54Copy
    55
    56```
    57# Individual Preferences
    58- @~/.claude/my-project-instructions.md
    59
    60```
    61
    62To avoid potential collisions, imports are not evaluated inside markdown code spans and code blocks.
    63
    64Copy
    65
    66```
    67This code span will not be treated as an import: `@anthropic-ai/claude-code`
    68
    69```
    70
    71Imported files can recursively import additional files, with a max-depth of 5 hops. You can see what memory files are loaded by running `/memory` command.
    72
    73## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#how-claude-looks-up-memories)  How Claude looks up memories
    74
    75Claude Code reads memories recursively: starting in the cwd, Claude Code recurses up to (but not including) the root directory _/_ and reads any CLAUDE.md or CLAUDE.local.md files it finds. This is especially convenient when working in large repositories where you run Claude Code in _foo/bar/_, and have memories in both _foo/CLAUDE.md_ and _foo/bar/CLAUDE.md_.
    76
    77Claude will also discover CLAUDE.md nested in subtrees under your current working directory. Instead of loading them at launch, they are only included when Claude reads files in those subtrees.
    78
    79## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#quickly-add-memories-with-the-%23-shortcut)  Quickly add memories with the `\#` shortcut
    80
    81The fastest way to add a memory is to start your input with the `#` character:
    82
    83Copy
    84
    85```
    86# Always use descriptive variable names
    87
    88```
    89
    90Youll be prompted to select which memory file to store this in.
    91
    92## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#directly-edit-memories-with-%2Fmemory)  Directly edit memories with `/memory`
    93
    94Use the `/memory` slash command during a session to open any memory file in your system editor for more extensive additions or organization.
    95
    96## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#set-up-project-memory)  Set up project memory
    97
    98Suppose you want to set up a CLAUDE.md file to store important project information, conventions, and frequently used commands.
    99
   100Bootstrap a CLAUDE.md for your codebase with the following command:
   101
   102Copy
   103
   104```
   105> /init
   106
   107```
   108
   109Tips:
   110
   111- Include frequently used commands (build, test, lint) to avoid repeated searches
   112- Document code style preferences and naming conventions
   113- Add important architectural patterns specific to your project
   114- CLAUDE.md memories can be used for both instructions shared with your team and for your individual preferences.
   115
   116## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#memory-best-practices)  Memory best practices
   117
   118- **Be specific**: Use 2-space indentation is better than Format code properly.
   119- **Use structure to organize**: Format each individual memory as a bullet point and group related memories under descriptive markdown headings.
   120- **Review periodically**: Update memories as your project evolves to ensure Claude is always using the most up to date information and context.
   121

[Anthropic home page![light logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/light.svg)![dark logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/dark.svg)](https://docs.anthropic.com/)

Manage Claude's memory

[Welcome](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/home) [Developer Platform](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/intro) [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview) [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/mcp) [API Reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages) [Resources](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/resources/overview) [Release Notes](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/release-notes/overview)

Claude Code can remember your preferences across sessions, like style guidelines and common commands in your workflow.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#determine-memory-type)  Determine memory type

Claude Code offers three memory locations, each serving a different purpose:

| Memory Type | Location | Purpose | Use Case Examples |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Project memory** | `./CLAUDE.md` | Team-shared instructions for the project | Project architecture, coding standards, common workflows |
| **User memory** | `~/.claude/CLAUDE.md` | Personal preferences for all projects | Code styling preferences, personal tooling shortcuts |
| **Project memory (local)** | `./CLAUDE.local.md` | Personal project-specific preferences | _(Deprecated, see below)_ Your sandbox URLs, preferred test data |

All memory files are automatically loaded into Claude Codes context when launched.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#claude-md-imports)  CLAUDE.md imports

CLAUDE.md files can import additional files using `@path/to/import` syntax. The following example imports 3 files:

Copy

```
See @README for project overview and @package.json for available npm commands for this project.

# Additional Instructions
- git workflow @docs/git-instructions.md

```

Both relative and absolute paths are allowed. In particular, importing files in users home dir is a convenient way for your team members to provide individual instructions that are not checked into the repository. Previously CLAUDE.local.md served a similar purpose, but is now deprecated in favor of imports since they work better across multiple git worktrees.

Copy

```
# Individual Preferences
- @~/.claude/my-project-instructions.md

```

To avoid potential collisions, imports are not evaluated inside markdown code spans and code blocks.

Copy

```
This code span will not be treated as an import: `@anthropic-ai/claude-code`

```

Imported files can recursively import additional files, with a max-depth of 5 hops. You can see what memory files are loaded by running `/memory` command.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#how-claude-looks-up-memories)  How Claude looks up memories

Claude Code reads memories recursively: starting in the cwd, Claude Code recurses up to (but not including) the root directory _/_ and reads any CLAUDE.md or CLAUDE.local.md files it finds. This is especially convenient when working in large repositories where you run Claude Code in _foo/bar/_, and have memories in both _foo/CLAUDE.md_ and _foo/bar/CLAUDE.md_.

Claude will also discover CLAUDE.md nested in subtrees under your current working directory. Instead of loading them at launch, they are only included when Claude reads files in those subtrees.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#quickly-add-memories-with-the-%23-shortcut)  Quickly add memories with the `\#` shortcut

The fastest way to add a memory is to start your input with the `#` character:

Copy

```
# Always use descriptive variable names

```

Youll be prompted to select which memory file to store this in.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#directly-edit-memories-with-%2Fmemory)  Directly edit memories with `/memory`

Use the `/memory` slash command during a session to open any memory file in your system editor for more extensive additions or organization.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#set-up-project-memory)  Set up project memory

Suppose you want to set up a CLAUDE.md file to store important project information, conventions, and frequently used commands.

Bootstrap a CLAUDE.md for your codebase with the following command:

Copy

```
> /init

```

Tips:

- Include frequently used commands (build, test, lint) to avoid repeated searches
- Document code style preferences and naming conventions
- Add important architectural patterns specific to your project
- CLAUDE.md memories can be used for both instructions shared with your team and for your individual preferences.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory\#memory-best-practices)  Memory best practices

- **Be specific**: Use 2-space indentation is better than Format code properly.
- **Use structure to organize**: Format each individual memory as a bullet point and group related memories under descriptive markdown headings.
- **Review periodically**: Update memories as your project evolves to ensure Claude is always using the most up to date information and context.

Was this page helpful?

YesNo

   661Tips to get the most value out of extended thinking:

   664

   671The way you prompt for thinking results in varying levels of thinking depth:
   672

   683## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows\#resume-previous-conversations)  Resume previous conversations
   684
   685Suppose youve been working on a task with Claude Code and need to continue where you left off in a later session.
   686
   687Claude Code provides two options for resuming previous conversations:
   688
   689- `--continue` to automatically continue the most recent conversation
   690- `--resume` to display a conversation picker
   691
   6921
   693
   694Continue the most recent conversation
   695
   696Copy
   697
   698```bash
   699claude --continue
   700
   701```
   702
   703This immediately resumes your most recent conversation without any prompts.
   704
   7052
   706
   707Continue in non-interactive mode
   708
   709Copy
   710
   711```bash
   712claude --continue --print "Continue with my task"
   713
   714```
   715
   716Use `--print` with `--continue` to resume the most recent conversation in non-interactive mode, perfect for scripts or automation.
   717
   7183
   719
   720Show conversation picker
   721
   722Copy
   723
   724```bash
   725claude --resume
   726
   727```
   728
   729This displays an interactive conversation selector showing:
   730
   731- Conversation start time
   732- Initial prompt or conversation summary
   733- Message count
   734
   735Use arrow keys to navigate and press Enter to select a conversation.
   736
   737Tips:
   738
   739- Conversation history is stored locally on your machine
   740- Use `--continue` for quick access to your most recent conversation
   741- Use `--resume` when you need to select a specific past conversation
   742- When resuming, youll see the entire conversation history before continuing
   743- The resumed conversation starts with the same model and configuration as the original
   744
   745How it works:
   746
   7471. **Conversation Storage**: All conversations are automatically saved locally with their full message history
   7482. **Message Deserialization**: When resuming, the entire message history is restored to maintain context
   7493. **Tool State**: Tool usage and results from the previous conversation are preserved
   7504. **Context Restoration**: The conversation resumes with all previous context intact
   751
   752Examples:
   753
   754Copy
   755
   756```bash
   757# Continue most recent conversation
   758claude --continue
   759
   760# Continue most recent conversation with a specific prompt
   761claude --continue --print "Show me our progress"
   762
   763# Show conversation picker
   764claude --resume
   765
   766# Continue most recent conversation in non-interactive mode
   767claude --continue --print "Run the tests again"
   768
   769```
   770
   771* * *
   772
   773## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows\#run-parallel-claude-code-sessions-with-git-worktrees)  Run parallel Claude Code sessions with Git worktrees
   774
   775Suppose you need to work on multiple tasks simultaneously with complete code isolation between Claude Code instances.
   776
   7771
   778
   779Understand Git worktrees
   780
   781Git worktrees allow you to check out multiple branches from the same
   782repository into separate directories. Each worktree has its own working
   783directory with isolated files, while sharing the same Git history. Learn
   784more in the [official Git worktree\\
   785documentation](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-worktree).
   786
   7872
   788
   789Create a new worktree
   790
   791Copy
   792
   793```bash
   794# Create a new worktree with a new branch
   795git worktree add ../project-feature-a -b feature-a
   796
   797# Or create a worktree with an existing branch
   798git worktree add ../project-bugfix bugfix-123
   799
   800```
   801
   802This creates a new directory with a separate working copy of your repository.
   803
   8043
   805
   806Run Claude Code in each worktree
   807
   808Copy
   809
   810```bash
   811# Navigate to your worktree
   812cd ../project-feature-a
   813
   814# Run Claude Code in this isolated environment
   815claude
   816
   817```
   818
   8194
   820
   821Run Claude in another worktree
   822
   823Copy
   824
   825```bash
   826cd ../project-bugfix
   827claude
   828
   829```
   830
   8315
   832
   833Manage your worktrees
   834
   835Copy
   836
   837```bash
   838# List all worktrees
   839git worktree list
   840
   841# Remove a worktree when done
   842git worktree remove ../project-feature-a
   843
   844```
   845
   846Tips:
   847
   848- Each worktree has its own independent file state, making it perfect for parallel Claude Code sessions
   849- Changes made in one worktree wont affect others, preventing Claude instances from interfering with each other
   850- All worktrees share the same Git history and remote connections
   851- For long-running tasks, you can have Claude working in one worktree while you continue development in another
   852- Use descriptive directory names to easily identify which task each worktree is for
   853- Remember to initialize your development environment in each new worktree according to your projects setup. Depending on your stack, this might include:
   854  - JavaScript projects: Running dependency installation ( `npm install`, `yarn`)
   855  - Python projects: Setting up virtual environments or installing with package managers
   856  - Other languages: Following your projects standard setup process
   857

   860## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows\#use-claude-as-a-unix-style-utility)  Use Claude as a unix-style utility

   862### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows\#add-claude-to-your-verification-process)  Add Claude to your verification process

   877    }

   884- Use Claude for automated code review in your CI/CD pipeline
   885- Customize the prompt to check for specific issues relevant to your project
   886- Consider creating multiple scripts for different types of verification
   887
   888### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows\#pipe-in%2C-pipe-out)  Pipe in, pipe out
   889
   890Suppose you want to pipe data into Claude, and get back data in a structured format.
   891
   892**Pipe data through Claude:**
   893
   894Copy
   895
   896```bash
   897cat build-error.txt | claude -p 'concisely explain the root cause of this build error' > output.txt
   898
   899```
   900
   901Tips:
   902
   903- Use pipes to integrate Claude into existing shell scripts
   904- Combine with other Unix tools for powerful workflows
   905- Consider using output-format for structured output
   906
   907### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows\#control-output-format)  Control output format
   908
   909Suppose you need Claudes output in a specific format, especially when integrating Claude Code into scripts or other tools.
   910
   9111
   912
   913Use text format (default)
   914
   915Copy
   916
   917```bash
   918cat data.txt | claude -p 'summarize this data' --output-format text > summary.txt
   919
   920```
   921
   922This outputs just Claudes plain text response (default behavior).
   923
   9242
   925
   926Use JSON format
   927
   928Copy
   929
   930```bash
   931cat code.py | claude -p 'analyze this code for bugs' --output-format json > analysis.json
   932
   933```
   934
   935This outputs a JSON array of messages with metadata including cost and duration.
   936
   9373
   938
   939Use streaming JSON format
   940
   941Copy
   942
   943```bash
   944cat log.txt | claude -p 'parse this log file for errors' --output-format stream-json
   945
   946```
   947
   948This outputs a series of JSON objects in real-time as Claude processes the request. Each message is a valid JSON object, but the entire output is not valid JSON if concatenated.
   949
   950Tips:
   951
   952- Use `--output-format text` for simple integrations where you just need Claudes response
   953- Use `--output-format json` when you need the full conversation log
   954- Use `--output-format stream-json` for real-time output of each conversation turn
   955
   956* * *
   957
   958## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows\#create-custom-slash-commands)  Create custom slash commands
   959
   960Claude Code supports custom slash commands that you can create to quickly execute specific prompts or tasks.
   961
   962For more details, see the [Slash commands](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/slash-commands) reference page.
   963
   964### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows\#create-project-specific-commands)  Create project-specific commands
   965
   966Suppose you want to create reusable slash commands for your project that all team members can use.
   967
   9681
   969
   970Create a commands directory in your project
   971
   972Copy
   973
   974```bash
   975mkdir -p .claude/commands
   976
   977```
   978
   9792
   980
   981Create a Markdown file for each command
   982
   983Copy
   984
   985```bash
   986echo "Analyze the performance of this code and suggest three specific optimizations:" > .claude/commands/optimize.md
   987
   988```
   989
   9903
   991
   992Use your custom command in Claude Code
   993
   994Copy
   995
   996```
   997> /optimize
   998
   999```
  1000
  1001Tips:
  1002
  1003- Command names are derived from the filename (e.g., `optimize.md` becomes `/optimize`)
  1004- You can organize commands in subdirectories (e.g., `.claude/commands/frontend/component.md` creates `/component` with (project:frontend) shown in the description)
  1005- Project commands are available to everyone who clones the repository
  1006- The Markdown file content becomes the prompt sent to Claude when the command is invoked
  1007
  1008### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows\#add-command-arguments-with-%24arguments)  Add command arguments with $ARGUMENTS
  1009
  1010Suppose you want to create flexible slash commands that can accept additional input from users.
  1011
  10121
  1013
  1014Create a command file with the $ARGUMENTS placeholder
  1015
  1016Copy
  1017
  1018```bash
  1019echo "Find and fix issue #$ARGUMENTS. Follow these steps: 1.
  1020Understand the issue described in the ticket 2. Locate the relevant code in
  1021our codebase 3. Implement a solution that addresses the root cause 4. Add
  1022appropriate tests 5. Prepare a concise PR description" >
  1023.claude/commands/fix-issue.md
  1024
  1025```
  1026
  10272
  1028
  1029Use the command with an issue number
  1030
  1031In your Claude session, use the command with arguments.
  1032
  1033Copy
  1034
  1035```
  1036> /fix-issue 123
  1037
  1038```
  1039
  1040This will replace $ARGUMENTS with 123 in the prompt.
  1041
  1042Tips:
  1043
  1044- The $ARGUMENTS placeholder is replaced with any text that follows the command
  1045- You can position $ARGUMENTS anywhere in your command template
  1046- Other useful applications: generating test cases for specific functions, creating documentation for components, reviewing code in particular files, or translating content to specified languages
  1047
  1048### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows\#create-personal-slash-commands)  Create personal slash commands
  1049
  1050Suppose you want to create personal slash commands that work across all your projects.
  1051
  10521
  1053
  1054Create a commands directory in your home folder
  1055
  1056Copy
  1057
  1058```bash
  1059mkdir -p ~/.claude/commands
  1060
  1061```
  1062
  10632
  1064
  1065Create a Markdown file for each command
  1066
  1067Copy
  1068
  1069```bash
  1070echo "Review this code for security vulnerabilities, focusing on:" >
  1071~/.claude/commands/security-review.md
  1072
  1073```
  1074
  10753
  1076
  1077Use your personal custom command
  1078
  1079Copy
  1080
  1081```
  1082> /security-review
  1083
  1084```
  1085
  1086Tips:
  1087
  1088- Personal commands show (user) in their description when listed with `/help`
  1089- Personal commands are only available to you and not shared with your team
  1090- Personal commands work across all your projects
  1091- You can use these for consistent workflows across different codebases
  1092
  1093* * *
  1094
  1095## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows\#ask-claude-about-its-capabilities)  Ask Claude about its capabilities
  1096
  1097Claude has built-in access to its documentation and can answer questions about its own features and limitations.
  1098
  1099### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows\#example-questions)  Example questions
  1100
  1101Copy
  1102
  1103```
  1104> can Claude Code create pull requests?
  1105
  1106```
  1107
  1108Copy
  1109
  1110```
  1111> how does Claude Code handle permissions?
  1112
  1113```
  1114
  1115Copy
  1116
  1117```
  1118> what slash commands are available?
  1119
  1120```
  1121
  1122Copy
  1123
  1124```
  1125> how do I use MCP with Claude Code?
  1126
  1127```
  1128
  1129Copy
  1130
  1131```
  1132> how do I configure Claude Code for Amazon Bedrock?
  1133
  1134```
  1135
  1136Copy
  1137
  1138```
  1139> what are the limitations of Claude Code?
  1140
  1141```
  1142
  1143Claude provides documentation-based answers to these questions. For executable examples and hands-on demonstrations, refer to the specific workflow sections above.
  1144
  1145Tips:
  1146
  1147- Claude always has access to the latest Claude Code documentation, regardless of the version youre using
  1148- Ask specific questions to get detailed answers
  1149- Claude can explain complex features like MCP integration, enterprise configurations, and advanced workflows
  1150
  1151* * *
  1152
  1153## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows\#next-steps)  Next steps
  1154
  1155[**Claude Code reference implementation** \\
  1156\\
  1157Clone our development container reference implementation.](https://github.com/anthropics/claude-code/tree/main/.devcontainer)
  1158
  1159Was this page helpful?
  1160
  1161YesNo
  1162
  1163[Quickstart](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/quickstart) [Claude Code SDK](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sdk)
  1164
  1165On this page
  1166
  1167- [Understand new codebases](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows#understand-new-codebases)
  1168- [Get a quick codebase overview](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows#get-a-quick-codebase-overview)
  1169- [Find relevant code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows#find-relevant-code)
  1170- [Fix bugs efficiently](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows#fix-bugs-efficiently)
  1171- [Refactor code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows#refactor-code)
  1172- [Use specialized subagents](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows#use-specialized-subagents)
  1173- [Work with tests](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows#work-with-tests)
  1174- [Create pull requests](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/common-workflows#create-pull-requests)

Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.
