1---
     2name: version-control-agent
     3description: Git and GitHub specialist managing commits, branches, PRs, and synchronization. Ensures perfect version control for multi-agent development. Use PROACTIVELY for all git operations. MANDATORY communication with this agent before code changes.
     4tools: Bash, Read, Write, Grep, Glob, TodoWrite
     5---
     6
     7You are the Version Control Agent - a Git and GitHub specialist responsible for managing all version control operations. You ensure perfect synchronization between all agents, maintain clean commit history, and facilitate smooth collaboration.
     8
     9## Core Responsibilities
    10
    11### 1. Branch Management
    12Manage feature branches strategically:
    13- Create branches for each feature/task
    14- Ensure proper naming conventions
    15- Manage branch protection rules
    16- Coordinate merges and rebases
    17- Handle merge conflicts
    18
    19### 2. Commit Management
    20Maintain clean commit history:
    21- Enforce conventional commits
    22- Ensure atomic commits
    23- Write clear commit messages
    24- Manage commit signing
    25- Squash when appropriate
    26
    27### 3. Pull Request Orchestration
    28Manage PRs effectively:
    29- Create comprehensive PR descriptions
    30- Ensure all checks pass
    31- Coordinate code reviews
    32- Manage PR templates
    33- Handle deployment triggers
    34
    35### 4. Multi-Agent Synchronization
    36Coordinate version control for all agents:
    37- Prevent conflicting changes
    38- Manage concurrent development
    39- Ensure proper rebasing
    40- Coordinate releases
    41- Track agent activities
    42
    43## Git Workflow Patterns
    44
    45### Branch Strategy
    46```bash
    47# Main branches
    48main          # Production-ready code
    49develop       # Development integration
    50
    51# Feature branches
    52feat/user-auth           # New features
    53fix/login-error         # Bug fixes
    54refactor/api-client     # Code refactoring
    55docs/setup-guide        # Documentation
    56test/e2e-coverage       # Testing improvements
    57```
    58
    59### Commit Conventions
    60```bash
    61# Format: <type>(<scope>): <subject>
    62
    63# Types
    64feat:     # New feature
    65fix:      # Bug fix
    66docs:     # Documentation
    67style:    # Formatting, no code change
    68refactor: # Code restructuring
    69test:     # Adding tests
    70chore:    # Maintenance
    71
    72# Examples
    73feat(auth): add Google OAuth login
    74fix(items): resolve deletion race condition
    75docs(api): update endpoint documentation
    76test(components): add ItemCard unit tests
    77```
    78
    79### Pre-Commit Workflow
    80```bash
    81# Before ANY commit, run:
    82npm run lint
    83npm run test:run
    84npm run build
    85
    86# Verify no secrets
    87git diff --staged | grep -E "(api_key|secret|token|password)" 
    88
    89# Check file sizes
    90find . -type f -size +1M | grep -v node_modules
    91```
    92
    93## Implementation Commands
    94
    95### Starting New Feature
    96```bash
    97# 1. Ensure clean working directory
    98git status
    99
   100# 2. Update from main
   101git checkout main
   102git pull origin main
   103
   104# 3. Create feature branch
   105git checkout -b feat/[feature-name]
   106
   107# 4. Verify branch
   108git branch --show-current
   109```
   110
   111### Committing Changes
   112```bash
   113# 1. Stage specific files (never use git add .)
   114git add src/components/NewComponent.tsx
   115git add src/components/NewComponent.test.tsx
   116git add src/components/NewComponent.stories.tsx
   117
   118# 2. Verify staged changes
   119git diff --staged
   120
   121# 3. Commit with conventional message
   122git commit -m "feat(components): add NewComponent with full test coverage
   123
   124- Implement responsive design
   125- Add accessibility features
   126- Include loading and error states
   127- Add comprehensive unit tests
   128- Create Storybook stories"
   129
   130# 4. Verify commit
   131git log --oneline -1
   132```
   133
   134### Creating Pull Requests
   135```bash
   136# 1. Push feature branch
   137git push -u origin feat/[feature-name]
   138
   139# 2. Create PR with gh CLI
   140gh pr create \
   141  --title "feat: Add user authentication" \
   142  --body "## Summary
   143  
   144  Implements complete user authentication flow with Firebase Auth.
   145  
   146  ## Changes
   147  - Add login/register pages
   148  - Implement auth store with Zustand
   149  - Add protected route wrapper
   150  - Include comprehensive error handling
   151  
   152  ## Testing
   153  - Unit tests: 95% coverage
   154  - E2E tests: All auth flows
   155  - Manual testing: Chrome, Firefox, Safari
   156  
   157  ## Checklist
   158  - [ ] Tests passing
   159  - [ ] Documentation updated
   160  - [ ] No console errors
   161  - [ ] Accessibility verified" \
   162  --base main
   163```
   164
   165### Handling Merge Conflicts
   166```bash
   167# 1. Update feature branch
   168git checkout feat/[feature-name]
   169git fetch origin
   170git rebase origin/main
   171
   172# 2. If conflicts occur
   173# Fix conflicts in editor
   174git add [resolved-files]
   175git rebase --continue
   176
   177# 3. Force push after rebase
   178git push --force-with-lease origin feat/[feature-name]
   179```
   180
   181## Multi-Agent Coordination
   182
   183### Agent Activity Tracking
   184```bash
   185# Create agent-specific commits
   186git commit -m "feat(backend): [Backend Agent] implement user API"
   187git commit -m "feat(frontend): [Frontend Agent] add user dashboard"
   188git commit -m "test(e2e): [Testing Agent] add auth flow tests"
   189git commit -m "docs(api): [Documentation Agent] update API reference"
   190```
   191
   192### Preventing Conflicts
   193Before any agent makes changes:
   194```bash
   195# 1. Check current branch
   196git branch --show-current
   197
   198# 2. Check for uncommitted changes
   199git status
   200
   201# 3. Check who's working on what
   202git branch -r | grep -E "(feat|fix|refactor)"
   203
   204# 4. Verify no conflicts with other agents
   205git fetch origin
   206git diff origin/main..HEAD --name-only
   207```
   208
   209### Release Management
   210```bash
   211# 1. Create release branch
   212git checkout -b release/v1.0.0
   213
   214# 2. Update version
   215npm version minor
   216
   217# 3. Generate changelog
   218git log --oneline --pretty=format:"- %s" main..HEAD > CHANGELOG_DRAFT.md
   219
   220# 4. Create release PR
   221gh pr create --title "Release v1.0.0" --body "$(cat CHANGELOG_DRAFT.md)"
   222
   223# 5. Tag release
   224git tag -a v1.0.0 -m "Release version 1.0.0"
   225git push origin v1.0.0
   226```
   227
   228## CI/CD Integration
   229
   230### Pre-Push Hooks
   231```bash
   232#!/bin/bash
   233# .git/hooks/pre-push
   234
   235# Run tests
   236npm run test:run || exit 1
   237
   238# Check types
   239npm run type-check || exit 1
   240
   241# Verify build
   242npm run build || exit 1
   243
   244echo " All checks passed"
   245```
   246
   247### GitHub Actions Triggers
   248```yaml
   249# Trigger workflows based on branch/PR
   250on:
   251  push:
   252    branches: [main, develop]
   253  pull_request:
   254    branches: [main]
   255    types: [opened, synchronize, reopened]
   256```
   257
   258## Best Practices
   259
   260### Commit Quality
   2611. **Atomic Commits**: One logical change per commit
   2622. **Clear Messages**: Explain why, not just what
   2633. **Reference Issues**: Link to GitHub issues
   2644. **Sign Commits**: Use GPG signing
   2655. **No Secrets**: Never commit sensitive data
   266
   267### Branch Hygiene
   2681. **Delete Merged Branches**: Keep repo clean
   2692. **Regular Rebasing**: Keep branches up-to-date
   2703. **Short-Lived Branches**: Merge frequently
   2714. **Descriptive Names**: Clear branch purposes
   2725. **Protection Rules**: Enforce quality gates
   273
   274### PR Standards
   2751. **Comprehensive Description**: What, why, how
   2762. **Small PRs**: Easier to review
   2773. **Screenshots**: For UI changes
   2784. **Testing Evidence**: Show tests pass
   2795. **Documentation**: Update relevant docs
   280
   281### Collaboration
   2821. **Communicate Changes**: Notify other agents
   2832. **Avoid Force Push**: Except after rebase
   2843. **Review Carefully**: Check for conflicts
   2854. **Tag Releases**: Semantic versioning
   2865. **Document Decisions**: In commit messages
   287
   288## Emergency Procedures
   289
   290### Reverting Changes
   291```bash
   292# Revert last commit
   293git revert HEAD
   294
   295# Revert specific commit
   296git revert [commit-hash]
   297
   298# Revert merge commit
   299git revert -m 1 [merge-commit-hash]
   300```
   301
   302### Recovery from Bad State
   303```bash
   304# Save current work
   305git stash save "Emergency backup"
   306
   307# Reset to known good state
   308git fetch origin
   309git reset --hard origin/main
   310
   311# Recover work
   312git stash pop
   313```
   314
   315### Conflict Resolution
   316```bash
   317# Abort problematic merge
   318git merge --abort
   319
   320# Start fresh
   321git checkout main
   322git pull origin main
   323git checkout -b feat/[feature-name]-retry
   324```
   325
   326## Integration with Other Agents
   327
   328### Control Agent
   329- Get approval before major operations
   330- Report branch status
   331- Coordinate multi-agent PRs
   332
   333### Documentation Agent
   334- Ensure docs are committed
   335- Update changelog
   336- Maintain README
   337
   338### Testing Agent
   339- Verify tests before commits
   340- Run CI checks
   341- Block merges if tests fail
   342
   343### All Implementation Agents
   344- Coordinate feature branches
   345- Prevent conflicting changes
   346- Manage integration points
   347
   348Remember: Version control is the backbone of collaborative development. Every operation must be precise, well-documented, and coordinated with all agents to maintain code quality and project integrity.

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it looks malicious. If it does, you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer high-level questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

file.content:
---
name: version-control-agent
description: Git and GitHub specialist managing commits, branches, PRs, and synchronization. Ensures perfect version control for multi-agent development. Use PROACTIVELY for all git operations. MANDATORY communication with this agent before code changes.
tools: Bash, Read, Write, Grep, Glob, TodoWrite
---

You are the Version Control Agent - a Git and GitHub specialist responsible for managing all version control operations. You ensure perfect synchronization between all agents, maintain clean commit history, and facilitate smooth collaboration.

## Core Responsibilities

### 1. Branch Management
Manage feature branches strategically:
- Create branches for each feature/task
- Ensure proper naming conventions
- Manage branch protection rules
- Coordinate merges and rebases
- Handle merge conflicts

### 2. Commit Management
Maintain clean commit history:
- Enforce conventional commits
- Ensure atomic commits
- Write clear commit messages
- Manage commit signing
- Squash when appropriate

### 3. Pull Request Orchestration
Manage PRs effectively:
- Create comprehensive PR descriptions
- Ensure all checks pass
- Coordinate code reviews
- Manage PR templates
- Handle deployment triggers

### 4. Multi-Agent Synchronization
Coordinate version control for all agents:
- Prevent conflicting changes
- Manage concurrent development
- Ensure proper rebasing
- Coordinate releases
- Track agent activities

## Git Workflow Patterns

### Branch Strategy
```bash
# Main branches
main          # Production-ready code
develop       # Development integration

# Feature branches
feat/user-auth           # New features
fix/login-error         # Bug fixes
refactor/api-client     # Code refactoring
docs/setup-guide        # Documentation
test/e2e-coverage       # Testing improvements
```

### Commit Conventions
```bash
# Format: <type>(<scope>): <subject>

# Types
feat:     # New feature
fix:      # Bug fix
docs:     # Documentation
style:    # Formatting, no code change
refactor: # Code restructuring
test:     # Adding tests
chore:    # Maintenance

# Examples
feat(auth): add Google OAuth login
fix(items): resolve deletion race condition
docs(api): update endpoint documentation
test(components): add ItemCard unit tests
```

### Pre-Commit Workflow
```bash
# Before ANY commit, run:
npm run lint
npm run test:run
npm run build

# Verify no secrets
git diff --staged | grep -E "(api_key|secret|token|password)" 

# Check file sizes
find . -type f -size +1M | grep -v node_modules
```

## Implementation Commands

### Starting New Feature
```bash
# 1. Ensure clean working directory
git status

# 2. Update from main
git checkout main
git pull origin main

# 3. Create feature branch
git checkout -b feat/[feature-name]

# 4. Verify branch
git branch --show-current
```

### Committing Changes
```bash
# 1. Stage specific files (never use git add .)
git add src/components/NewComponent.tsx
git add src/components/NewComponent.test.tsx
git add src/components/NewComponent.stories.tsx

# 2. Verify staged changes
git diff --staged

# 3. Commit with conventional message
git commit -m "feat(components): add NewComponent with full test coverage

- Implement responsive design
- Add accessibility features
- Include loading and error states
- Add comprehensive unit tests
- Create Storybook stories"

# 4. Verify commit
git log --oneline -1
```

### Creating Pull Requests
```bash
# 1. Push feature branch
git push -u origin feat/[feature-name]

# 2. Create PR with gh CLI
gh pr create \
  --title "feat: Add user authentication" \
  --body "## Summary
  
  Implements complete user authentication flow with Firebase Auth.
  
  ## Changes
  - Add login/register pages
  - Implement auth store with Zustand
  - Add protected route wrapper
  - Include comprehensive error handling
  
  ## Testing
  - Unit tests: 95% coverage
  - E2E tests: All auth flows
  - Manual testing: Chrome, Firefox, Safari
  
  ## Checklist
  - [ ] Tests passing
  - [ ] Documentation updated
  - [ ] No console errors
  - [ ] Accessibility verified" \
  --base main
```

### Handling Merge Conflicts
```bash
# 1. Update feature branch
git checkout feat/[feature-name]
git fetch origin
git rebase origin/main

# 2. If conflicts occur
# Fix conflicts in editor
git add [resolved-files]
git rebase --continue

# 3. Force push after rebase
git push --force-with-lease origin feat/[feature-name]
```

## Multi-Agent Coordination

### Agent Activity Tracking
```bash
# Create agent-specific commits
git commit -m "feat(backend): [Backend Agent] implement user API"
git commit -m "feat(frontend): [Frontend Agent] add user dashboard"
git commit -m "test(e2e): [Testing Agent] add auth flow tests"
git commit -m "docs(api): [Documentation Agent] update API reference"
```

### Preventing Conflicts
Before any agent makes changes:
```bash
# 1. Check current branch
git branch --show-current

# 2. Check for uncommitted changes
git status

# 3. Check who's working on what
git branch -r | grep -E "(feat|fix|refactor)"

# 4. Verify no conflicts with other agents
git fetch origin
git diff origin/main..HEAD --name-only
```

### Release Management
```bash
# 1. Create release branch
git checkout -b release/v1.0.0

# 2. Update version
npm version minor

# 3. Generate changelog
git log --oneline --pretty=format:"- %s" main..HEAD > CHANGELOG_DRAFT.md

# 4. Create release PR
gh pr create --title "Release v1.0.0" --body "$(cat CHANGELOG_DRAFT.md)"

# 5. Tag release
git tag -a v1.0.0 -m "Release version 1.0.0"
git push origin v1.0.0
```

## CI/CD Integration

### Pre-Push Hooks
```bash
#!/bin/bash
# .git/hooks/pre-push

# Run tests
npm run test:run || exit 1

# Check types
npm run type-check || exit 1

# Verify build
npm run build || exit 1

echo " All checks passed"
```

### GitHub Actions Triggers
```yaml
# Trigger workflows based on branch/PR
on:
  push:
    branches: [main, develop]
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]
    types: [opened, synchronize, reopened]
```

## Best Practices

### Commit Quality
1. **Atomic Commits**: One logical change per commit
2. **Clear Messages**: Explain why, not just what
3. **Reference Issues**: Link to GitHub issues
4. **Sign Commits**: Use GPG signing
5. **No Secrets**: Never commit sensitive data

### Branch Hygiene
1. **Delete Merged Branches**: Keep repo clean
2. **Regular Rebasing**: Keep branches up-to-date
3. **Short-Lived Branches**: Merge frequently
4. **Descriptive Names**: Clear branch purposes
5. **Protection Rules**: Enforce quality gates

### PR Standards
1. **Comprehensive Description**: What, why, how
2. **Small PRs**: Easier to review
3. **Screenshots**: For UI changes
4. **Testing Evidence**: Show tests pass
5. **Documentation**: Update relevant docs

### Collaboration
1. **Communicate Changes**: Notify other agents
2. **Avoid Force Push**: Except after rebase
3. **Review Carefully**: Check for conflicts
4. **Tag Releases**: Semantic versioning
5. **Document Decisions**: In commit messages

## Emergency Procedures

### Reverting Changes
```bash
# Revert last commit
git revert HEAD

# Revert specific commit
git revert [commit-hash]

# Revert merge commit
git revert -m 1 [merge-commit-hash]
```

### Recovery from Bad State
```bash
# Save current work
git stash save "Emergency backup"

# Reset to known good state
git fetch origin
git reset --hard origin/main

# Recover work
git stash pop
```

### Conflict Resolution
```bash
# Abort problematic merge
git merge --abort

# Start fresh
git checkout main
git pull origin main
git checkout -b feat/[feature-name]-retry
```

## Integration with Other Agents

### Control Agent
- Get approval before major operations
- Report branch status
- Coordinate multi-agent PRs

### Documentation Agent
- Ensure docs are committed
- Update changelog
- Maintain README

### Testing Agent
- Verify tests before commits
- Run CI checks
- Block merges if tests fail

### All Implementation Agents
- Coordinate feature branches
- Prevent conflicting changes
- Manage integration points

Remember: Version control is the backbone of collaborative development. Every operation must be precise, well-documented, and coordinated with all agents to maintain code quality and project integrity.

1---
     2url: "https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents"
     3title: "Subagents - Anthropic"
     4---
     5
     6[Anthropic home page![light logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/light.svg)![dark logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/dark.svg)](https://docs.anthropic.com/)
     7
     8English
     9
    10Search...
    11
    12Ctrl K
    13
    14Search...
    15
    16Navigation
    17
    18Build with Claude Code
    19
    20Subagents
    21
    22[Welcome](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/home) [Developer Platform](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/intro) [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview) [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/mcp) [API Reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages) [Resources](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/resources/overview) [Release Notes](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/release-notes/overview)
    23
    24Custom subagents in Claude Code are specialized AI assistants that can be invoked to handle specific types of tasks. They enable more efficient problem-solving by providing task-specific configurations with customized system prompts, tools and a separate context window.
    25
    26## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#what-are-subagents%3F)  What are subagents?
    27
    28Subagents are pre-configured AI personalities that Claude Code can delegate tasks to. Each subagent:
    29
    30- Has a specific purpose and expertise area
    31- Uses its own context window separate from the main conversation
    32- Can be configured with specific tools its allowed to use
    33- Includes a custom system prompt that guides its behavior
    34
    35When Claude Code encounters a task that matches a subagents expertise, it can delegate that task to the specialized subagent, which works independently and returns results.
    36
    37## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#key-benefits)  Key benefits
    38
    39## Context preservation
    40
    41Each subagent operates in its own context, preventing pollution of the main conversation and keeping it focused on high-level objectives.
    42
    43## Specialized expertise
    44
    45Subagents can be fine-tuned with detailed instructions for specific domains, leading to higher success rates on designated tasks.
    46
    47## Reusability
    48
    49Once created, subagents can be used across different projects and shared with your team for consistent workflows.
    50
    51## Flexible permissions
    52
    53Each subagent can have different tool access levels, allowing you to limit powerful tools to specific subagent types.
    54
    55## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#quick-start)  Quick start
    56
    57To create your first subagent:
    58
    591
    60
    61Open the subagents interface
    62
    63Run the following command:
    64
    65Copy
    66
    67```
    68/agents
    69
    70```
    71
    722
    73
    74Select 'Create New Agent'
    75
    76Choose whether to create a project-level or user-level subagent
    77
    783
    79
    80Define the subagent
    81
    82- **Recommended**: Generate with Claude first, then customize to make it yours
    83- Describe your subagent in detail and when it should be used
    84- Select the tools you want to grant access to (or leave blank to inherit all tools)
    85- The interface shows all available tools, making selection easy
    86- If youre generating with Claude, you can also edit the system prompt in your own editor by pressing `e`
    87
    884
    89
    90Save and use
    91
    92Your subagent is now available! Claude will use it automatically when appropriate, or you can invoke it explicitly:
    93
    94Copy
    95
    96```
    97> Use the code-reviewer subagent to check my recent changes
    98
    99```
   100
   101## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#subagent-configuration)  Subagent configuration
   102
   103### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#file-locations)  File locations
   104
   105Subagents are stored as Markdown files with YAML frontmatter in two possible locations:
   106
   107| Type | Location | Scope | Priority |
   108| --- | --- | --- | --- |
   109| **Project subagents** | `.claude/agents/` | Available in current project | Highest |
   110| **User subagents** | `~/.claude/agents/` | Available across all projects | Lower |
   111
   112When subagent names conflict, project-level subagents take precedence over user-level subagents.
   113
   114### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#file-format)  File format
   115
   116Each subagent is defined in a Markdown file with this structure:
   117
   118Copy
   119
   120```markdown
   121---
   122name: your-sub-agent-name
   123description: Description of when this subagent should be invoked
   124tools: tool1, tool2, tool3  # Optional - inherits all tools if omitted
   125---
   126
   127Your subagent's system prompt goes here. This can be multiple paragraphs
   128and should clearly define the subagent's role, capabilities, and approach
   129to solving problems.
   130
   131Include specific instructions, best practices, and any constraints
   132the subagent should follow.
   133
   134```
   135
   136#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#configuration-fields)  Configuration fields
   137
   138| Field | Required | Description |
   139| --- | --- | --- |
   140| `name` | Yes | Unique identifier using lowercase letters and hyphens |
   141| `description` | Yes | Natural language description of the subagents purpose |
   142| `tools` | No | Comma-separated list of specific tools. If omitted, inherits all tools from the main thread |
   143
   144### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#available-tools)  Available tools
   145
   146Subagents can be granted access to any of Claude Codes internal tools. See the [tools documentation](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings#tools-available-to-claude) for a complete list of available tools.
   147
   148**Recommended:** Use the `/agents` command to modify tool access - it provides an interactive interface that lists all available tools, including any connected MCP server tools, making it easier to select the ones you need.
   149
   150You have two options for configuring tools:
   151
   152- **Omit the `tools` field** to inherit all tools from the main thread (default), including MCP tools
   153- **Specify individual tools** as a comma-separated list for more granular control (can be edited manually or via `/agents`)
   154
   155**MCP Tools**: Subagents can access MCP tools from configured MCP servers. When the `tools` field is omitted, subagents inherit all MCP tools available to the main thread.
   156
   157## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#managing-subagents)  Managing subagents
   158
   159### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#using-the-%2Fagents-command-recommended)  Using the /agents command (Recommended)
   160
   161The `/agents` command provides a comprehensive interface for subagent management:
   162
   163Copy
   164
   165```
   166/agents
   167
   168```
   169
   170This opens an interactive menu where you can:
   171
   172- View all available subagents (built-in, user, and project)
   173- Create new subagents with guided setup
   174- Edit existing custom subagents, including their tool access
   175- Delete custom subagents
   176- See which subagents are active when duplicates exist
   177- **Easily manage tool permissions** with a complete list of available tools
   178
   179### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#direct-file-management)  Direct file management
   180
   181You can also manage subagents by working directly with their files:
   182
   183Copy
   184
   185```bash
   186# Create a project subagent
   187mkdir -p .claude/agents
   188echo '---
   189name: test-runner
   190description: Use proactively to run tests and fix failures
   191---
   192
   193You are a test automation expert. When you see code changes, proactively run the appropriate tests. If tests fail, analyze the failures and fix them while preserving the original test intent.' > .claude/agents/test-runner.md
   194
   195# Create a user subagent
   196mkdir -p ~/.claude/agents
   197# ... create subagent file
   198
   199```
   200
   201## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#using-subagents-effectively)  Using subagents effectively
   202
   203### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#automatic-delegation)  Automatic delegation
   204
   205Claude Code proactively delegates tasks based on:
   206
   207- The task description in your request
   208- The `description` field in subagent configurations
   209- Current context and available tools
   210
   211To encourage more proactive subagent use, include phrases like use PROACTIVELY or MUST BE USED in your `description` field.
   212
   213### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#explicit-invocation)  Explicit invocation
   214
   215Request a specific subagent by mentioning it in your command:
   216
   217Copy
   218
   219```
   220> Use the test-runner subagent to fix failing tests
   221> Have the code-reviewer subagent look at my recent changes
   222> Ask the debugger subagent to investigate this error
   223
   224```
   225
   226## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#example-subagents)  Example subagents
   227
   228### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#code-reviewer)  Code reviewer
   229
   230Copy
   231
   232```markdown
   233---
   234name: code-reviewer
   235description: Expert code review specialist. Proactively reviews code for quality, security, and maintainability. Use immediately after writing or modifying code.
   236tools: Read, Grep, Glob, Bash
   237---
   238
   239You are a senior code reviewer ensuring high standards of code quality and security.
   240
   241When invoked:
   2421. Run git diff to see recent changes
   2432. Focus on modified files
   2443. Begin review immediately
   245
   246Review checklist:
   247- Code is simple and readable
   248- Functions and variables are well-named
   249- No duplicated code
   250- Proper error handling
   251- No exposed secrets or API keys
   252- Input validation implemented
   253- Good test coverage
   254- Performance considerations addressed
   255
   256Provide feedback organized by priority:
   257- Critical issues (must fix)
   258- Warnings (should fix)
   259- Suggestions (consider improving)
   260
   261Include specific examples of how to fix issues.
   262
   263```
   264
   265### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#debugger)  Debugger
   266
   267Copy
   268
   269```markdown
   270---
   271name: debugger
   272description: Debugging specialist for errors, test failures, and unexpected behavior. Use proactively when encountering any issues.
   273tools: Read, Edit, Bash, Grep, Glob
   274---
   275
   276You are an expert debugger specializing in root cause analysis.
   277
   278When invoked:
   2791. Capture error message and stack trace
   2802. Identify reproduction steps
   2813. Isolate the failure location
   2824. Implement minimal fix
   2835. Verify solution works
   284
   285Debugging process:
   286- Analyze error messages and logs
   287- Check recent code changes
   288- Form and test hypotheses
   289- Add strategic debug logging
   290- Inspect variable states
   291
   292For each issue, provide:
   293- Root cause explanation
   294- Evidence supporting the diagnosis
   295- Specific code fix
   296- Testing approach
   297- Prevention recommendations
   298
   299Focus on fixing the underlying issue, not just symptoms.
   300
   301```
   302
   303### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#data-scientist)  Data scientist
   304
   305Copy
   306
   307```markdown
   308---
   309name: data-scientist
   310description: Data analysis expert for SQL queries, BigQuery operations, and data insights. Use proactively for data analysis tasks and queries.
   311tools: Bash, Read, Write
   312---
   313
   314You are a data scientist specializing in SQL and BigQuery analysis.
   315
   316When invoked:
   3171. Understand the data analysis requirement
   3182. Write efficient SQL queries
   3193. Use BigQuery command line tools (bq) when appropriate
   3204. Analyze and summarize results
   3215. Present findings clearly
   322
   323Key practices:
   324- Write optimized SQL queries with proper filters
   325- Use appropriate aggregations and joins
   326- Include comments explaining complex logic
   327- Format results for readability
   328- Provide data-driven recommendations
   329
   330For each analysis:
   331- Explain the query approach
   332- Document any assumptions
   333- Highlight key findings
   334- Suggest next steps based on data
   335
   336Always ensure queries are efficient and cost-effective.
   337
   338```
   339
   340## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#best-practices)  Best practices
   341
   342- **Start with Claude-generated agents**: We highly recommend generating your initial subagent with Claude and then iterating on it to make it personally yours. This approach gives you the best results - a solid foundation that you can customize to your specific needs.
   343
   344- **Design focused subagents**: Create subagents with single, clear responsibilities rather than trying to make one subagent do everything. This improves performance and makes subagents more predictable.
   345
   346- **Write detailed prompts**: Include specific instructions, examples, and constraints in your system prompts. The more guidance you provide, the better the subagent will perform.
   347
   348- **Limit tool access**: Only grant tools that are necessary for the subagents purpose. This improves security and helps the subagent focus on relevant actions.
   349
   350- **Version control**: Check project subagents into version control so your team can benefit from and improve them collaboratively.
   351
   352
   353## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#advanced-usage)  Advanced usage
   354
   355### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#chaining-subagents)  Chaining subagents
   356
   357For complex workflows, you can chain multiple subagents:
   358
   359Copy
   360
   361```
   362> First use the code-analyzer subagent to find performance issues, then use the optimizer subagent to fix them
   363
   364```
   365
   366### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#dynamic-subagent-selection)  Dynamic subagent selection
   367
   368Claude Code intelligently selects subagents based on context. Make your `description` fields specific and action-oriented for best results.
   369
   370## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#performance-considerations)  Performance considerations
   371
   372- **Context efficiency**: Agents help preserve main context, enabling longer overall sessions
   373- **Latency**: Subagents start off with a clean slate each time they are invoked and may add latency as they gather context that they require to do their job effectively.
   374
   375## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#related-documentation)  Related documentation
   376
   377- [Slash commands](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/slash-commands) \- Learn about other built-in commands
   378- [Settings](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings) \- Configure Claude Code behavior
   379- [Hooks](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks) \- Automate workflows with event handlers
   380
   381Was this page helpful?
   382

---
url: "https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents"
title: "Subagents - Anthropic"
---

[Anthropic home page![light logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/light.svg)![dark logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/dark.svg)](https://docs.anthropic.com/)

English

Search...

Ctrl K

Search...

Navigation

Build with Claude Code

Subagents

[Welcome](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/home) [Developer Platform](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/intro) [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview) [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/mcp) [API Reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages) [Resources](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/resources/overview) [Release Notes](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/release-notes/overview)

Custom subagents in Claude Code are specialized AI assistants that can be invoked to handle specific types of tasks. They enable more efficient problem-solving by providing task-specific configurations with customized system prompts, tools and a separate context window.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#what-are-subagents%3F)  What are subagents?

Subagents are pre-configured AI personalities that Claude Code can delegate tasks to. Each subagent:

- Has a specific purpose and expertise area
- Uses its own context window separate from the main conversation
- Can be configured with specific tools its allowed to use
- Includes a custom system prompt that guides its behavior

When Claude Code encounters a task that matches a subagents expertise, it can delegate that task to the specialized subagent, which works independently and returns results.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#key-benefits)  Key benefits

## Context preservation

Each subagent operates in its own context, preventing pollution of the main conversation and keeping it focused on high-level objectives.

## Specialized expertise

Subagents can be fine-tuned with detailed instructions for specific domains, leading to higher success rates on designated tasks.

## Reusability

Once created, subagents can be used across different projects and shared with your team for consistent workflows.

## Flexible permissions

Each subagent can have different tool access levels, allowing you to limit powerful tools to specific subagent types.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#quick-start)  Quick start

To create your first subagent:

1

Open the subagents interface

Run the following command:

Copy

```
/agents

```

2

Select 'Create New Agent'

Choose whether to create a project-level or user-level subagent

3

Define the subagent

- **Recommended**: Generate with Claude first, then customize to make it yours
- Describe your subagent in detail and when it should be used
- Select the tools you want to grant access to (or leave blank to inherit all tools)
- The interface shows all available tools, making selection easy
- If youre generating with Claude, you can also edit the system prompt in your own editor by pressing `e`

4

Save and use

Your subagent is now available! Claude will use it automatically when appropriate, or you can invoke it explicitly:

Copy

```
> Use the code-reviewer subagent to check my recent changes

```

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#subagent-configuration)  Subagent configuration

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#file-locations)  File locations

Subagents are stored as Markdown files with YAML frontmatter in two possible locations:

| Type | Location | Scope | Priority |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| **Project subagents** | `.claude/agents/` | Available in current project | Highest |
| **User subagents** | `~/.claude/agents/` | Available across all projects | Lower |

When subagent names conflict, project-level subagents take precedence over user-level subagents.

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#file-format)  File format

Each subagent is defined in a Markdown file with this structure:

Copy

```markdown
---
name: your-sub-agent-name
description: Description of when this subagent should be invoked
tools: tool1, tool2, tool3  # Optional - inherits all tools if omitted
---

Your subagent's system prompt goes here. This can be multiple paragraphs
and should clearly define the subagent's role, capabilities, and approach
to solving problems.

Include specific instructions, best practices, and any constraints
the subagent should follow.

```

#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#configuration-fields)  Configuration fields

| Field | Required | Description |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `name` | Yes | Unique identifier using lowercase letters and hyphens |
| `description` | Yes | Natural language description of the subagents purpose |
| `tools` | No | Comma-separated list of specific tools. If omitted, inherits all tools from the main thread |

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#available-tools)  Available tools

Subagents can be granted access to any of Claude Codes internal tools. See the [tools documentation](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings#tools-available-to-claude) for a complete list of available tools.

**Recommended:** Use the `/agents` command to modify tool access - it provides an interactive interface that lists all available tools, including any connected MCP server tools, making it easier to select the ones you need.

You have two options for configuring tools:

- **Omit the `tools` field** to inherit all tools from the main thread (default), including MCP tools
- **Specify individual tools** as a comma-separated list for more granular control (can be edited manually or via `/agents`)

**MCP Tools**: Subagents can access MCP tools from configured MCP servers. When the `tools` field is omitted, subagents inherit all MCP tools available to the main thread.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#managing-subagents)  Managing subagents

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#using-the-%2Fagents-command-recommended)  Using the /agents command (Recommended)

The `/agents` command provides a comprehensive interface for subagent management:

Copy

```
/agents

```

This opens an interactive menu where you can:

- View all available subagents (built-in, user, and project)
- Create new subagents with guided setup
- Edit existing custom subagents, including their tool access
- Delete custom subagents
- See which subagents are active when duplicates exist
- **Easily manage tool permissions** with a complete list of available tools

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#direct-file-management)  Direct file management

You can also manage subagents by working directly with their files:

Copy

```bash
# Create a project subagent
mkdir -p .claude/agents
echo '---
name: test-runner
description: Use proactively to run tests and fix failures
---

You are a test automation expert. When you see code changes, proactively run the appropriate tests. If tests fail, analyze the failures and fix them while preserving the original test intent.' > .claude/agents/test-runner.md

# Create a user subagent
mkdir -p ~/.claude/agents
# ... create subagent file

```

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#using-subagents-effectively)  Using subagents effectively

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#automatic-delegation)  Automatic delegation

Claude Code proactively delegates tasks based on:

- The task description in your request
- The `description` field in subagent configurations
- Current context and available tools

To encourage more proactive subagent use, include phrases like use PROACTIVELY or MUST BE USED in your `description` field.

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#explicit-invocation)  Explicit invocation

Request a specific subagent by mentioning it in your command:

Copy

```
> Use the test-runner subagent to fix failing tests
> Have the code-reviewer subagent look at my recent changes
> Ask the debugger subagent to investigate this error

```

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#example-subagents)  Example subagents

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#code-reviewer)  Code reviewer

Copy

```markdown
---
name: code-reviewer
description: Expert code review specialist. Proactively reviews code for quality, security, and maintainability. Use immediately after writing or modifying code.
tools: Read, Grep, Glob, Bash
---

You are a senior code reviewer ensuring high standards of code quality and security.

When invoked:
1. Run git diff to see recent changes
2. Focus on modified files
3. Begin review immediately

Review checklist:
- Code is simple and readable
- Functions and variables are well-named
- No duplicated code
- Proper error handling
- No exposed secrets or API keys
- Input validation implemented
- Good test coverage
- Performance considerations addressed

Provide feedback organized by priority:
- Critical issues (must fix)
- Warnings (should fix)
- Suggestions (consider improving)

Include specific examples of how to fix issues.

```

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#debugger)  Debugger

Copy

```markdown
---
name: debugger
description: Debugging specialist for errors, test failures, and unexpected behavior. Use proactively when encountering any issues.
tools: Read, Edit, Bash, Grep, Glob
---

You are an expert debugger specializing in root cause analysis.

When invoked:
1. Capture error message and stack trace
2. Identify reproduction steps
3. Isolate the failure location
4. Implement minimal fix
5. Verify solution works

Debugging process:
- Analyze error messages and logs
- Check recent code changes
- Form and test hypotheses
- Add strategic debug logging
- Inspect variable states

For each issue, provide:
- Root cause explanation
- Evidence supporting the diagnosis
- Specific code fix
- Testing approach
- Prevention recommendations

Focus on fixing the underlying issue, not just symptoms.

```

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#data-scientist)  Data scientist

Copy

```markdown
---
name: data-scientist
description: Data analysis expert for SQL queries, BigQuery operations, and data insights. Use proactively for data analysis tasks and queries.
tools: Bash, Read, Write
---

You are a data scientist specializing in SQL and BigQuery analysis.

When invoked:
1. Understand the data analysis requirement
2. Write efficient SQL queries
3. Use BigQuery command line tools (bq) when appropriate
4. Analyze and summarize results
5. Present findings clearly

Key practices:
- Write optimized SQL queries with proper filters
- Use appropriate aggregations and joins
- Include comments explaining complex logic
- Format results for readability
- Provide data-driven recommendations

For each analysis:
- Explain the query approach
- Document any assumptions
- Highlight key findings
- Suggest next steps based on data

Always ensure queries are efficient and cost-effective.

```

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#best-practices)  Best practices

- **Start with Claude-generated agents**: We highly recommend generating your initial subagent with Claude and then iterating on it to make it personally yours. This approach gives you the best results - a solid foundation that you can customize to your specific needs.

- **Design focused subagents**: Create subagents with single, clear responsibilities rather than trying to make one subagent do everything. This improves performance and makes subagents more predictable.

- **Write detailed prompts**: Include specific instructions, examples, and constraints in your system prompts. The more guidance you provide, the better the subagent will perform.

- **Limit tool access**: Only grant tools that are necessary for the subagents purpose. This improves security and helps the subagent focus on relevant actions.

- **Version control**: Check project subagents into version control so your team can benefit from and improve them collaboratively.


## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#advanced-usage)  Advanced usage

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#chaining-subagents)  Chaining subagents

For complex workflows, you can chain multiple subagents:

Copy

```
> First use the code-analyzer subagent to find performance issues, then use the optimizer subagent to fix them

```

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#dynamic-subagent-selection)  Dynamic subagent selection

Claude Code intelligently selects subagents based on context. Make your `description` fields specific and action-oriented for best results.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#performance-considerations)  Performance considerations

- **Context efficiency**: Agents help preserve main context, enabling longer overall sessions
- **Latency**: Subagents start off with a clean slate each time they are invoked and may add latency as they gather context that they require to do their job effectively.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/sub-agents\#related-documentation)  Related documentation

- [Slash commands](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/slash-commands) \- Learn about other built-in commands
- [Settings](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/settings) \- Configure Claude Code behavior
- [Hooks](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks) \- Automate workflows with event handlers

     2url: "https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup"
     3title: "Set up Claude Code - Anthropic"
     4---
     5
     6[Anthropic home page![light logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/light.svg)![dark logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/dark.svg)](https://docs.anthropic.com/)

     9

    19
    20Set up Claude Code
    21
    22[Welcome](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/home) [Developer Platform](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/intro) [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview) [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/mcp) [API Reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages) [Resources](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/resources/overview) [Release Notes](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/release-notes/overview)
    23
    24## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#system-requirements)  System requirements
    25
    26- **Operating Systems**: macOS 10.15+, Ubuntu 20.04+/Debian 10+, or Windows 10+ (with WSL 1, WSL 2, or Git for Windows)
    27- **Hardware**: 4GB+ RAM
    28- **Software**: [Node.js 18+](https://nodejs.org/en/download)
    29- **Network**: Internet connection required for authentication and AI processing
    30- **Shell**: Works best in Bash, Zsh or Fish
    31- **Location**: [Anthropic supported countries](https://www.anthropic.com/supported-countries)
    32
    33## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#standard-installation)  Standard installation
    34
    35To install Claude Code, run the following command:
    36
    37Copy
    38
    39```sh
    40npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code
    41
    42```
    43
    44Do NOT use `sudo npm install -g` as this can lead to permission issues and security risks.
    45If you encounter permission errors, see [configure Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/troubleshooting#linux-permission-issues) for recommended solutions.
    46
    47Some users may be automatically migrated to an improved installation method.
    48Run `claude doctor` after installation to check your installation type.
    49
    50After the installation process completes, navigate to your project and start Claude Code:
    51
    52Copy
    53
    54```bash
    55cd your-awesome-project
    56claude
    57
    58```
    59
    60Claude Code offers the following authentication options:
    61
    621. **Anthropic Console**: The default option. Connect through the Anthropic Console and complete the OAuth process. Requires active billing at [console.anthropic.com](https://console.anthropic.com/).
    632. **Claude App (with Pro or Max plan)**: Subscribe to Claudes [Pro or Max plan](https://www.anthropic.com/pricing) for a unified subscription that includes both Claude Code and the web interface. Get more value at the same price point while managing your account in one place. Log in with your Claude.ai account. During launch, choose the option that matches your subscription type.
    643. **Enterprise platforms**: Configure Claude Code to use [Amazon Bedrock or Google Vertex AI](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/third-party-integrations) for enterprise deployments with your existing cloud infrastructure.
    65
    66Claude Code securely stores your credentials. See [Credential Management](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/iam#credential-management) for details.
    67
    68## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#windows-setup)  Windows setup
    69
    70**Option 1: Claude Code within WSL**
    71
    72- Both WSL 1 and WSL 2 are supported
    73
    74**Option 2: Claude Code on native Windows with Git Bash**
    75
    76- Requires [Git for Windows](https://git-scm.com/downloads/win)
    77- For portable Git installations, specify the path to your `bash.exe`:
    78
    79
    80
    81
    82
    83Copy
    84
    85
    86
    87
    88
    89
    90
    91
    92
    93```powershell
    94$env:CLAUDE_CODE_GIT_BASH_PATH="C:\Program Files\Git\bin\bash.exe"
    95
    96```
    97
    98
    99## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#alternative-installation-methods)  Alternative installation methods
   100
   101Claude Code offers multiple installation methods to suit different environments.
   102
   103If you encounter any issues during installation, consult the [troubleshooting guide](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/troubleshooting#linux-permission-issues).
   104
   105Run `claude doctor` after installation to check your installation type and version.
   106
   107### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#global-npm-installation)  Global npm installation
   108
   109Traditional method shown in the [install steps above](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup#install-and-authenticate)
   110
   111### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#native-binary-installation-beta)  Native binary installation (Beta)
   112
   113If you have an existing installation of Claude Code, use `claude install` to start the native binary installation.
   114
   115For a fresh install, run the following command:
   116
   117**macOS, Linux, WSL:**
   118
   119Copy
   120
   121```bash
   122# Install stable version (default)
   123curl -fsSL https://claude.ai/install.sh | bash
   124
   125# Install latest version
   126curl -fsSL https://claude.ai/install.sh | bash -s latest
   127
   128# Install specific version number
   129curl -fsSL https://claude.ai/install.sh | bash -s 1.0.58
   130
   131```
   132
   133**Windows PowerShell:**
   134
   135Copy
   136
   137```powershell
   138# Install stable version (default)
   139irm https://claude.ai/install.ps1 | iex
   140
   141# Install latest version
   142& ([scriptblock]::Create((irm https://claude.ai/install.ps1))) latest
   143
   144# Install specific version number
   145& ([scriptblock]::Create((irm https://claude.ai/install.ps1))) 1.0.58
   146
   147```
   148
   149The native Claude Code installer is supported on macOS, Linux, and Windows.
   150
   151Make sure that you remove any outdated aliases or symlinks.
   152Once your installation is complete, run `claude doctor` to verify the installation.
   153
   154### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#local-installation)  Local installation
   155
   156- After global install via npm, use `claude migrate-installer` to move to local
   157- Avoids autoupdater npm permission issues
   158- Some users may be automatically migrated to this method
   159
   160## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#running-on-aws-or-gcp)  Running on AWS or GCP
   161
   162By default, Claude Code uses Anthropics API.
   163
   164For details on running Claude Code on AWS or GCP, see [third-party integrations](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/third-party-integrations).
   165
   166## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#update-claude-code)  Update Claude Code
   167
   168### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#auto-updates)  Auto updates
   169
   170Claude Code automatically keeps itself up to date to ensure you have the latest features and security fixes.
   171
   172- **Update checks**: Performed on startup and periodically while running
   173- **Update process**: Downloads and installs automatically in the background
   174- **Notifications**: Youll see a notification when updates are installed
   175- **Applying updates**: Updates take effect the next time you start Claude Code
   176
   177**Disable auto-updates:**
   178
   179Copy
   180
   181```bash
   182# Via configuration
   183claude config set autoUpdates false --global
   184
   185# Or via environment variable
   186export DISABLE_AUTOUPDATER=1
   187
   188```
   189
   190### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#update-manually)  Update manually
   191
   192Copy
   193
   194```bash
   195claude update
   196
   197```

---
url: "https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup"
title: "Set up Claude Code - Anthropic"
---

[Anthropic home page![light logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/light.svg)![dark logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/dark.svg)](https://docs.anthropic.com/)

English

Search...

Ctrl K

Search...

Navigation

Administration

Set up Claude Code

[Welcome](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/home) [Developer Platform](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/intro) [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview) [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/mcp) [API Reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages) [Resources](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/resources/overview) [Release Notes](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/release-notes/overview)

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#system-requirements)  System requirements

- **Operating Systems**: macOS 10.15+, Ubuntu 20.04+/Debian 10+, or Windows 10+ (with WSL 1, WSL 2, or Git for Windows)
- **Hardware**: 4GB+ RAM
- **Software**: [Node.js 18+](https://nodejs.org/en/download)
- **Network**: Internet connection required for authentication and AI processing
- **Shell**: Works best in Bash, Zsh or Fish
- **Location**: [Anthropic supported countries](https://www.anthropic.com/supported-countries)

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#standard-installation)  Standard installation

To install Claude Code, run the following command:

Copy

```sh
npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code

```

Do NOT use `sudo npm install -g` as this can lead to permission issues and security risks.
If you encounter permission errors, see [configure Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/troubleshooting#linux-permission-issues) for recommended solutions.

Some users may be automatically migrated to an improved installation method.
Run `claude doctor` after installation to check your installation type.

After the installation process completes, navigate to your project and start Claude Code:

Copy

```bash
cd your-awesome-project
claude

```

Claude Code offers the following authentication options:

1. **Anthropic Console**: The default option. Connect through the Anthropic Console and complete the OAuth process. Requires active billing at [console.anthropic.com](https://console.anthropic.com/).
2. **Claude App (with Pro or Max plan)**: Subscribe to Claudes [Pro or Max plan](https://www.anthropic.com/pricing) for a unified subscription that includes both Claude Code and the web interface. Get more value at the same price point while managing your account in one place. Log in with your Claude.ai account. During launch, choose the option that matches your subscription type.
3. **Enterprise platforms**: Configure Claude Code to use [Amazon Bedrock or Google Vertex AI](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/third-party-integrations) for enterprise deployments with your existing cloud infrastructure.

Claude Code securely stores your credentials. See [Credential Management](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/iam#credential-management) for details.

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#windows-setup)  Windows setup

**Option 1: Claude Code within WSL**

- Both WSL 1 and WSL 2 are supported

**Option 2: Claude Code on native Windows with Git Bash**

- Requires [Git for Windows](https://git-scm.com/downloads/win)
- For portable Git installations, specify the path to your `bash.exe`:





Copy









```powershell
$env:CLAUDE_CODE_GIT_BASH_PATH="C:\Program Files\Git\bin\bash.exe"

```


## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#alternative-installation-methods)  Alternative installation methods

Claude Code offers multiple installation methods to suit different environments.

If you encounter any issues during installation, consult the [troubleshooting guide](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/troubleshooting#linux-permission-issues).

Run `claude doctor` after installation to check your installation type and version.

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#global-npm-installation)  Global npm installation

Traditional method shown in the [install steps above](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup#install-and-authenticate)

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#native-binary-installation-beta)  Native binary installation (Beta)

If you have an existing installation of Claude Code, use `claude install` to start the native binary installation.

For a fresh install, run the following command:

**macOS, Linux, WSL:**

Copy

```bash
# Install stable version (default)
curl -fsSL https://claude.ai/install.sh | bash

# Install latest version
curl -fsSL https://claude.ai/install.sh | bash -s latest

# Install specific version number
curl -fsSL https://claude.ai/install.sh | bash -s 1.0.58

```

**Windows PowerShell:**

Copy

```powershell
# Install stable version (default)
irm https://claude.ai/install.ps1 | iex

# Install latest version
& ([scriptblock]::Create((irm https://claude.ai/install.ps1))) latest

# Install specific version number
& ([scriptblock]::Create((irm https://claude.ai/install.ps1))) 1.0.58

```

The native Claude Code installer is supported on macOS, Linux, and Windows.

Make sure that you remove any outdated aliases or symlinks.
Once your installation is complete, run `claude doctor` to verify the installation.

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#local-installation)  Local installation

- After global install via npm, use `claude migrate-installer` to move to local
- Avoids autoupdater npm permission issues
- Some users may be automatically migrated to this method

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#running-on-aws-or-gcp)  Running on AWS or GCP

By default, Claude Code uses Anthropics API.

For details on running Claude Code on AWS or GCP, see [third-party integrations](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/third-party-integrations).

## [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#update-claude-code)  Update Claude Code

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#auto-updates)  Auto updates

Claude Code automatically keeps itself up to date to ensure you have the latest features and security fixes.

- **Update checks**: Performed on startup and periodically while running
- **Update process**: Downloads and installs automatically in the background
- **Notifications**: Youll see a notification when updates are installed
- **Applying updates**: Updates take effect the next time you start Claude Code

**Disable auto-updates:**

Copy

```bash
# Via configuration
claude config set autoUpdates false --global

# Or via environment variable
export DISABLE_AUTOUPDATER=1

```

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup\#update-manually)  Update manually

Copy

```bash
claude update

```

Was this page helpful?

YesNo

[Development containers](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/devcontainer) [Identity and Access Management](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/iam)

- [Windows setup](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup#windows-setup)
- [Alternative installation methods](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup#alternative-installation-methods)
- [Global npm installation](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup#global-npm-installation)
- [Native binary installation (Beta)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup#native-binary-installation-beta)
- [Local installation](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup#local-installation)
- [Running on AWS or GCP](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup#running-on-aws-or-gcp)
- [Update Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup#update-claude-code)
- [Auto updates](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/setup#auto-updates)

    21
    22[Welcome](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/home) [Developer Platform](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/intro) [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview) [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/mcp) [API Reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages) [Resources](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/resources/overview) [Release Notes](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/release-notes/overview)
    23
    24### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#themes-and-appearance)  Themes and appearance
    25
    26Claude cannot control the theme of your terminal. Thats handled by your terminal application. You can match Claude Codes theme to your terminal any time via the `/config` command.
    27
    28### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#line-breaks)  Line breaks
    29
    30You have several options for entering linebreaks into Claude Code:
    31
    32- **Quick escape**: Type `\` followed by Enter to create a newline
    33- **Keyboard shortcut**: Set up a keybinding to insert a newline
    34
    35#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#set-up-shift%2Benter-vs-code-or-iterm2-%3A)  Set up Shift+Enter (VS Code or iTerm2):
    36
    37Run `/terminal-setup` within Claude Code to automatically configure Shift+Enter.
    38
    39#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#set-up-option%2Benter-vs-code%2C-iterm2-or-macos-terminal-app-%3A)  Set up Option+Enter (VS Code, iTerm2 or macOS Terminal.app):
    40
    41**For Mac Terminal.app:**
    42
    431. Open Settings  Profiles  Keyboard
    442. Check Use Option as Meta Key
    45
    46**For iTerm2 and VS Code terminal:**
    47
    481. Open Settings  Profiles  Keys
    492. Under General, set Left/Right Option key to Esc+
    50
    51### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#notification-setup)  Notification setup
    52
    53Never miss when Claude completes a task with proper notification configuration:
    54
    55#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#terminal-bell-notifications)  Terminal bell notifications
    56
    57Enable sound alerts when tasks complete:
    58
    59Copy
    60
    61```sh
    62claude config set --global preferredNotifChannel terminal_bell
    63
    64```
    65
    66**For macOS users**: Dont forget to enable notification permissions in System Settings  Notifications  \[Your Terminal App\].
    67
    68#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#iterm-2-system-notifications)  iTerm 2 system notifications
    69
    70For iTerm 2 alerts when tasks complete:
    71
    721. Open iTerm 2 Preferences
    732. Navigate to Profiles  Terminal
    743. Enable Silence bell and Filter Alerts  Send escape sequence-generated alerts
    754. Set your preferred notification delay
    76
    77Note that these notifications are specific to iTerm 2 and not available in the default macOS Terminal.
    78
    79#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#custom-notification-hooks)  Custom notification hooks
    80
    81For advanced notification handling, you can create [notification hooks](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks#notification) to run your own logic.
    82
    83### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#handling-large-inputs)  Handling large inputs
    84
    85When working with extensive code or long instructions:
    86
    87- **Avoid direct pasting**: Claude Code may struggle with very long pasted content
    88- **Use file-based workflows**: Write content to a file and ask Claude to read it
    89- **Be aware of VS Code limitations**: The VS Code terminal is particularly prone to truncating long pastes
    90
    91### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#vim-mode)  Vim Mode
    92
    93Claude Code supports a subset of Vim keybindings that can be enabled with `/vim` or configured via `/config`.
    94
    95The supported subset includes:
    96
    97- Mode switching: `Esc` (to NORMAL), `i`/ `I`, `a`/ `A`, `o`/ `O` (to INSERT)
    98- Navigation: `h`/ `j`/ `k`/ `l`, `w`/ `e`/ `b`, `0`/ `$`/ `^`, `gg`/ `G`
    99- Editing: `x`, `dw`/ `de`/ `db`/ `dd`/ `D`, `cw`/ `ce`/ `cb`/ `cc`/ `C`, `.` (repeat)
   100

---
url: "https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config"
title: "Optimize your terminal setup - Anthropic"
---

[Anthropic home page![light logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/light.svg)![dark logo](https://mintlify.s3.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/anthropic/logo/dark.svg)](https://docs.anthropic.com/)

English

Search...

Ctrl K

Search...

Navigation

Configuration

Optimize your terminal setup

[Welcome](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/home) [Developer Platform](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/intro) [Claude Code](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/overview) [Model Context Protocol (MCP)](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/mcp) [API Reference](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/api/messages) [Resources](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/resources/overview) [Release Notes](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/release-notes/overview)

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#themes-and-appearance)  Themes and appearance

Claude cannot control the theme of your terminal. Thats handled by your terminal application. You can match Claude Codes theme to your terminal any time via the `/config` command.

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#line-breaks)  Line breaks

You have several options for entering linebreaks into Claude Code:

- **Quick escape**: Type `\` followed by Enter to create a newline
- **Keyboard shortcut**: Set up a keybinding to insert a newline

#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#set-up-shift%2Benter-vs-code-or-iterm2-%3A)  Set up Shift+Enter (VS Code or iTerm2):

Run `/terminal-setup` within Claude Code to automatically configure Shift+Enter.

#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#set-up-option%2Benter-vs-code%2C-iterm2-or-macos-terminal-app-%3A)  Set up Option+Enter (VS Code, iTerm2 or macOS Terminal.app):

**For Mac Terminal.app:**

1. Open Settings  Profiles  Keyboard
2. Check Use Option as Meta Key

**For iTerm2 and VS Code terminal:**

1. Open Settings  Profiles  Keys
2. Under General, set Left/Right Option key to Esc+

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#notification-setup)  Notification setup

Never miss when Claude completes a task with proper notification configuration:

#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#terminal-bell-notifications)  Terminal bell notifications

Enable sound alerts when tasks complete:

Copy

```sh
claude config set --global preferredNotifChannel terminal_bell

```

**For macOS users**: Dont forget to enable notification permissions in System Settings  Notifications  \[Your Terminal App\].

#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#iterm-2-system-notifications)  iTerm 2 system notifications

For iTerm 2 alerts when tasks complete:

1. Open iTerm 2 Preferences
2. Navigate to Profiles  Terminal
3. Enable Silence bell and Filter Alerts  Send escape sequence-generated alerts
4. Set your preferred notification delay

Note that these notifications are specific to iTerm 2 and not available in the default macOS Terminal.

#### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#custom-notification-hooks)  Custom notification hooks

For advanced notification handling, you can create [notification hooks](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/hooks#notification) to run your own logic.

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#handling-large-inputs)  Handling large inputs

When working with extensive code or long instructions:

- **Avoid direct pasting**: Claude Code may struggle with very long pasted content
- **Use file-based workflows**: Write content to a file and ask Claude to read it
- **Be aware of VS Code limitations**: The VS Code terminal is particularly prone to truncating long pastes

### [](https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/terminal-config\#vim-mode)  Vim Mode

Claude Code supports a subset of Vim keybindings that can be enabled with `/vim` or configured via `/config`.

The supported subset includes:

- Mode switching: `Esc` (to NORMAL), `i`/ `I`, `a`/ `A`, `o`/ `O` (to INSERT)
- Navigation: `h`/ `j`/ `k`/ `l`, `w`/ `e`/ `b`, `0`/ `$`/ `^`, `gg`/ `G`
- Editing: `x`, `dw`/ `de`/ `db`/ `dd`/ `D`, `cw`/ `ce`/ `cb`/ `cc`/ `C`, `.` (repeat)

content.text:
Based on my analysis of your sub-agents and the official Claude Code documentation, I've identified several critical issues that explain why they're not working optimally:

##  Key Issues Identified

### 1. **Missing Control-Agent Reporting**
None of your sub-agents have explicit instructions to report to the control-agent, which is a critical coordination mechanism.

### 2. **Insufficient Commit Frequency**
The sub-agents lack clear directives about when and how often to commit, leading to infrequent commits.

### 3. **Missing Proactive Language**
The descriptions don't use the recommended "PROACTIVELY" and "MUST BE USED" language for automatic delegation.

### 4. **Incomplete Tool Sets**
Some agents are missing critical tools needed for their responsibilities.

### 5. **No Coordination Protocols**
Agents lack clear instructions on how to coordinate with each other and the control-agent.

edits.old_string: You are the Backend Agent - a specialist in Firebase backend development with TypeScript. You implement secure, scalable backend solutions following the template's strict patterns and best practices.
edits.new_string:
You are the Backend Agent - a specialist in Firebase backend development with TypeScript. You implement secure, scalable backend solutions following the template's strict patterns and best practices.

##  CRITICAL COORDINATION REQUIREMENTS

### Before Starting Any Work
1. **MANDATORY**: Report to control-agent with your planned actions
2. Check for conflicts with other agents
3. Verify no uncommitted changes exist
4. Create feature branch if needed

### During Work
1. **COMMIT FREQUENTLY**: After each major step (every 30-60 minutes max)
2. Use conventional commit messages with [Backend Agent] prefix
3. Push changes to feature branch regularly
4. Update TodoWrite with progress

### After Completing Work
1. **MANDATORY**: Report to control-agent with completion status
2. Create pull request if feature is complete
3. Update documentation
4. Notify other agents of changes

edits.old_string: Remember: Backend security and reliability are critical. Always follow the template's patterns and implement comprehensive error handling and validation.
edits.new_string:
## Integration with Other Agents

### Control Agent Coordination
- **BEFORE**: Report planned backend changes and scope
- **DURING**: Update on major milestones and blockers
- **AFTER**: Report completion status and next steps

### Version Control Integration
- Use version-control-agent for complex git operations
- Commit after each implementation step
- Create descriptive commit messages
- Push feature branches regularly

### Documentation Agent Collaboration
- Update API documentation after endpoint changes
- Document security rule modifications
- Capture environment variable changes
- Note breaking changes for migration guides

## Commit Frequency Protocol

### Commit After Each:
1. Firebase configuration changes
2. New type definitions
3. Security rule implementations
4. Cloud Function deployments
5. Database structure modifications
6. API endpoint additions/changes

### Commit Message Format
```bash
feat(backend): [Backend Agent] implement user authentication

- Add Firebase Auth configuration
- Create user profile schema
- Implement JWT validation
- Add security rules for user data

Co-authored-by: Backend Agent <backend@agents.local>
```

Remember: Backend security and reliability are critical. Always follow the template's patterns, implement comprehensive error handling and validation, and maintain constant coordination with the control-agent.

edits.old_string: ## Implementation Patterns
edits.new_string:
## Workflow Integration

### Starting Backend Work
```typescript
// 1. Report to control-agent
" Backend Agent starting work on [feature/task]"
"Planned actions: [list of actions]"
"Estimated time: [duration]"
"Dependencies: [other agents/tasks]"

// 2. Create feature branch via version-control-agent
// 3. Begin implementation
// 4. Commit frequently
```

### During Implementation
```typescript
// After each major step:
" [Backend Agent] Completed: [specific step]"
"Next: [next step]"
"Blockers: [any issues]"

// Commit immediately:
git add [changed files]
git commit -m "feat(backend): [Backend Agent] [description]"
```

### Completing Backend Work
```typescript
// 1. Final commit and push
// 2. Update documentation
// 3. Report to control-agent
" Backend Agent completed: [feature/task]"
"Files changed: [list]"
"Tests: [status]"
"Ready for: [next steps]"
```

## Implementation Patterns
